INPUT:question:
How do I rename a local Git branch?
How do I rename a local branch which has not yet been pushed to a remote repository?
Related:
Rename master branch for both local and remote Git repositories
How do I rename both a Git local and remote branch name?
OUTPUT:answer:
To rename a local Git branch, you can use the command git branch -m old_branch_name new_branch_name. This will rename the local branch from "old_branch_name" to "new_branch_name".

If you want to rename a local branch which has not yet been pushed to a remote repository, you can first rename the local branch with the above command, then use the command git push origin :old_branch_name new_branch_name to delete the old branch and push the new branch to the remote repository.

If you want to rename both a local and remote branch, you would first rename the local branch as described above, then use the command git push origin :old_branch_name new_branch_name to delete the old remote branch and push the new branch. Then use the command git push origin -u new_branch_name to set the new remote branch as the default.

INPUT:question:
How do I undo the most recent local commits in Git?
I accidentally committed the wrong files to Git, but didn't push the commit to the server yet.
How do I undo those commits from the local repository?
OUTPUT:answer:
You can use the git reset command to undo the most recent local commits in Git. The specific command you would use depends on how far back you want to reset the repository.

To undo the most recent commit, use the command:
git reset HEAD~
This will reset the repository to the state of the commit before the most recent one.

If you want to reset to a specific commit, you can use the commit's hash instead of HEAD~
git reset <commit_hash>
This will reset the repository to the state of the specific commit you specify.

Be careful with using the above command as it will remove all commits after the specified commit and make them unrecoverable.

Once you reset the repository, you can then recommit the files you want to keep.

INPUT:question:
Which equals operator (== vs ===) should be used in JavaScript comparisons?
I'm using JSLint to go through JavaScript, and it's returning many suggestions to replace == (two equals signs) with === (three equals signs) when doing things like comparing idSele_UNVEHtype.value.length == 0 inside of an if statement.
Is there a performance benefit to replacing == with ===? 
Any performance improvement would be welcomed as many comparison operators exist.
If no type conversion takes place, would there be a performance gain over ==?
OUTPUT:answer:
In JavaScript, it is generally recommended to use the "strict equality" operator (===) when comparing values, rather than the "loose equality" operator (==).
Using the strict equality operator will prevent unexpected type conversions from occurring.
For example, if you use the loose equality operator to compare the number 0 and the string "0", the comparison will return true, because JavaScript will automatically convert the string to a number before making the comparison.

Using === instead of == in JavaScript, it will not perform any type coercion and will only return true if the operands have the same type and the same value.

There may be some performance benefits to using the strict equality operator in certain cases, as it avoids the need for JavaScript to perform type conversions. However, in most cases the difference in performance is likely to be negligible.

So, it's a good practice to use === instead of == to avoid unexpected results, and in some cases it may also give a slight performance gain.

INPUT:question:
How do I delete a Git branch locally and remotely?
Failed Attempts to Delete a Remote Branch:
$ git branch -d remotes/origin/bugfix
error: branch 'remotes/origin/bugfix' not found.
$ git branch -d origin/bugfix
error: branch 'origin/bugfix' not found.
$ git branch -rd origin/bugfix
Deleted remote branch origin/bugfix (was 2a14ef7).
$ git push
Everything up-to-date
$ git pull
From github.com:gituser/gitproject
* [new branch] bugfix -> origin/bugfix
Already up-to-date.
How do I properly delete the remotes/origin/bugfix branch both locally and remotely?
OUTPUT:answer:
To delete a local branch, you can use the command git branch -d branch_name. In your case, you can use the command git branch -d bugfix to delete the local branch.

To delete a remote branch, you need to use the command git push origin --delete branch_name. In your case, you can use the command git push origin --delete bugfix.

If you want to delete the remote branch and local branch in one command you can use this command git push origin --delete bugfix && git branch -d bugfix

It is important to note that when you delete a remote branch, it will only delete the branch on the remote repository and not on your local repository. To delete the local copy of the remote branch, you will need to run the local delete command after the remote delete command.

Also, when you delete a branch, it should not have any unmerged commits. If it has any unmerged commits, git will prevent deletion and you need to merge those commits or use -D instead of -d to delete the branch forcefully.

In your case, since you are trying to delete a remote branch, it seems that you are trying to delete the remote branch using the local branch name, the correct way to delete remote branch is by using the remote branch name and not local branch name, so it should be git push origin --delete remotes/origin/bugfix or simply git push origin --delete bugfix

INPUT:question:
What are metaclasses in Python?
What are metaclasses? What are they used for?
OUTPUT:answer:
In Python, a class is an object that defines the behavior and properties of other objects. A metaclass is a class that defines the behavior and properties of a class. In other words, a metaclass is the class of a class.

Metaclasses are used to create custom class behavior, such as adding methods or properties to all instances of a particular class or group of classes. They can also be used for advanced metaprogramming, such as creating new types of classes dynamically or modifying the behavior of the class creation process.

For example, you could use a metaclass to automatically add a method to all classes that inherit from a certain base class, or to create a singleton class that only allows one instance of the class to be created.

In python, The type is the default metaclass for all classes, and it is responsible for creating the class object and its behavior. However, you can define your own metaclasses by subclassing type and implementing custom behavior.

It's worth noting that metaclasses are considered an advanced feature of Python and are not commonly used in everyday programming. It is also considered as a somewhat complex topic and might not be needed in most cases.

INPUT:question:
How can I safely create a nested directory?
I am writing a file using Python. How do I check:
if the parent file directory exists
if it does not - create the directory
OUTPUT:answer:
In Python, you can use the os module to safely create a nested directory. The os.makedirs() function can be used to create a directory, including any necessary parent directories. Here is an example of how to use this function to create a nested directory:

import os

directory = 'path/to/nested/directory'

if not os.path.exists(directory):
    os.makedirs(directory)
This will check if the parent directory exists, if not it will create the directory.

Another way to achieve this is using the os.path.exists() and os.makedirs() together:

import os

directory = 'path/to/nested/directory'

if not os.path.exists(directory):
    os.makedirs(directory, exist_ok=True)
Here, the exist_ok parameter is set to True, which means that if the directory already exists, no exception will be raised.

You can also use the os.path.isdir() function to check if the parent directory exists and os.mkdir() function to create a directory, if it does not exist.

import os

directory = 'path/to/nested/directory'
parent_directory = os.path.dirname(directory)

if not os.path.isdir(parent_directory):
    os.mkdir(parent_directory)
os.mkdir(directory)
os.path.dirname() will give you the parent directory of a given directory path.

It is worth noting that using non-standard features can make your code less portable, as it may not work with other compilers or platforms. INPUT:question:
How do I clone all remote branches?
My master and development branches are tracked remotely on GitHub. How do I clone both these branches?
OUTPUT:answer:
To clone all remote branches, you can use the command git clone --mirror <remote repository URL>. This will create a bare repository with all the branches and their full commit history.

To clone specific branches, you can use the command git clone -b <branch name> <remote repository URL>. This will clone only the specified branch and its commit history. To clone multiple branches, repeat the command for each branch you want to clone. For example, to clone the master and development branches, you can run the following commands:

git clone -b master <remote repository URL>
git clone -b development <remote repository URL>
This will create two separate directories, one for each branch, with the specified branch checked out and ready for development.

Note that using the git clone --mirror will create a bare repository, where you can't do any development and it's intended to be used as a remote repository.

INPUT:question:
What is the difference between "let" and "var"?
ECMAScript 6 introduced the let statement.
I've heard that it's described as a local variable, but I'm still not quite sure how it behaves differently than the var keyword.
What are the differences? When should let be used instead of var?
OUTPUT:answer:
In JavaScript, let and var are used to declare variables. However, they have some key differences in how they behave.

The var keyword is used to declare a variable in JavaScript, and it is function scoped. This means that a variable declared with var is accessible within the entire function it was declared in, and it's hoisted to the top of the function.

The let keyword, introduced in ECMAScript 6, is also used to declare variables but it's block scoped. This means that a variable declared with let is accessible only within the block it was declared in, and it's not hoisted to the top of the block.

One of the most important difference between let and var is the temporal dead zone (TDZ). The variable declared with let inside a block cannot be accessed before it is declared. However, variables declared with var are accessible before they are declared, this is due to hoisting.

In terms of when to use let instead of var, it's generally recommended to use let when you need a variable that is only accessible within a specific block, such as within a loop or an if statement. This can help you avoid errors caused by accidentally accessing or modifying a variable from the wrong scope.

INPUT:question:
How do I squash my last N commits together?
How do I squash my last N commits together into one commit?
OUTPUT:answer:
You can squash your last N commits together into one commit using the git rebase command.

Here's an example of how you can squash your last 3 commits together:

# Make sure you are on the branch you want to squash commits on
git rebase -i HEAD~3

This will open an editor where you will see a list of your last 3 commits, with the most recent at the top. You will see the word "pick" before each commit. Replace "pick" on all the commits that you want to squash together with "squash" or "s" (all except the first one), save the file and exit.

You will be prompted to edit the commit message for the new, squashed commit. You should make sure to provide a good summary of the changes made in the squashed commits.

When you're finished editing the message, save the file and exit the editor.

git push -f origin <branch-name>


Then force push to the remote branch, this will update the remote branch to have the new squashed commit.

It's important to note that squashing commits rewrites the commit history, so it's a good practice to only squash commits that haven't been pushed yet. If you squash commits that have already been pushed to a remote repository, you'll need to force push the changes, which can cause problems if other people are also working on the same branch.

INPUT:question:
How do I add an empty directory to a Git repository?
How do I add an empty directory (that contains no files) to a Git repository?
OUTPUT:answer:
You can add an empty directory to a Git repository by creating the directory in your local file system and then adding and committing it using Git. Here are the steps:

Navigate to the parent directory of where you want to create the new empty directory.

Run the command mkdir directory-name to create the new directory.

Run the command git add directory-name to stage the new directory for commit.

Run the command git commit -m "added empty directory directory-name" to commit the new directory to the repository.

Alternatively, You can also create a new file in the empty directory and then commit that file as you would with any other file. This will add the directory to the repository as well.

Note: If you want to add an already existing empty directory to git you can use touch command to create a new empty file in the directory , and then follow the above steps.

INPUT:question:
Accessing the index in 'for' loops
How do I access the index while iterating over a sequence with a for loop?
xs = [8, 23, 45]
for x in xs:
    print("item #{} = {}".format(index, x))
Desired output:
item #1 = 8
item #2 = 23
item #3 = 45
OUTPUT:answer:
Using the enumerate function:
Copy code
xs = [8, 23, 45]
for index, x in enumerate(xs):
    print("item #{} = {}".format(index+1, x))
This will give you the desired output:

Copy code
item #1 = 8
item #2 = 23
item #3 = 45
The enumerate function returns an iterator that produces tuples containing the index and the value of the elements in the sequence. By default, the index starts at 0, but you can set it to start at any value by passing a second argument to the enumerate function.

What is the difference between px, dip, dp, and sp?
What is the difference between the units of measure
px, dip, dp, and sp?
OUTPUT:answer:
In Android development, there are several units of measure that can be used to specify the size and position of elements in a layout. The most commonly used units are:

px (pixels): This is the most basic unit of measure and represents a physical pixel on the device's screen. It is the default unit for specifying dimensions in Android.

dip (density-independent pixels): This unit of measure scales with the density of the device's screen. On a high-density screen, 1 dip is equal to 2 pixels, while on a low-density screen, 1 dip is equal to 1 pixel. Using dip units helps ensure that the layout of your app looks consistent across different screen densities.

dp (density-independent pixels): This unit of measure is equivalent to dip and it is an alias of it.

sp (scale-independent pixels): This unit of measure is similar to dip, but it is also scaled based on the user's preferred text size. It is used for specifying font sizes.

In short,

px is fixed and does not scale with the screen density.
dip/dp is relative to the screen density, but does not take into account the user's preferred text size.
sp is relative to both the screen density and the user's preferred text size.

In general, it's best to use sp for font sizes, and dp/dip for other dimensions, as this will ensure that your layout looks consistent across different devices and user settings

INPUT:question:
What does the "yield" keyword do?
What is the use of the yield keyword in Python? What does it do?
For example, I'm trying to understand this code1:
def _get_child_candidates(self, distance, min_dist, max_dist):
    if self._leftchild and distance - max_dist < self._median:
        yield self._leftchild
    if self._rightchild and distance + max_dist >= self._median:
        yield self._rightchild  
And this is the caller:
result, candidates = [], [self]
while candidates:
    node = candidates.pop()
    distance = node._get_dist(obj)
    if distance <= max_dist and distance >= min_dist:
        result.extend(node._values)
    candidates.extend(node._get_child_candidates(distance, min_dist, max_dist))
return result
What happens when the method _get_child_candidates is called?
Is a list returned? A single element? Is it called again? When will subsequent calls stop?
1. This piece of code was written by Jochen Schulz (jrschulz), who made a great Python library for metric spaces. This is the link to the complete source: Module mspace.
OUTPUT:answer:
The "yield"

In the _get_child_candidates method, the yield

When the method _get_child_candidates is called, it doesn't return anything. Instead, it returns a generator object, which is then used in the line "candidates.extend(node._get_child_candidates(distance, min_dist, max_dist))" to add the leftchild or rightchild node to the candidates list, one at a time.

The generator will stop

In this case, the generator will stop yielding values when there are no more leftchild or rightchild nodes to return, as there are no more iterations to be done.

INPUT:question:
How is Docker different from a virtual machine?
I keep rereading the Docker documentation to try to understand the difference between Docker and a full VM. How does it manage to provide a full filesystem, isolated networking environment, etc. without being as heavy?
Why is deploying software to a Docker image (if that's the right term) easier than simply deploying to a consistent production environment?
OUTPUT:answer:
Docker and virtual machines (VMs) are both technologies that allow you to run software in an isolated environment, but they work in different ways.

A virtual machine is a software implementation of a physical machine that runs on top of a host operating system. Each VM runs its own operating system and has its own virtualized hardware, such as CPU, memory, and storage. This allows you to run multiple operating systems on the same physical machine, but it also makes VMs relatively heavy and resource-intensive.

Docker, on the other hand, is a containerization technology that allows you to package software and its dependencies into a single container. A container is a lightweight, standalone executable package that includes everything needed to run the software, including the code, runtime, system tools, libraries, and settings. Because containers share the host operating system kernel, they are much more lightweight and efficient than VMs.

When deploying software to a Docker image, it eliminates the "works on my machine" problem. It enables developers to package an application with all of its dependencies into a single container, which can run on any machine that has Docker installed. This makes it easier to deploy and run the same application in different environments, such as development, staging, and production, without worrying about compatibility issues.

In summary, Docker provides an isolated environment for running software that is lightweight and efficient, because it shares the host operating system kernel, while virtual machines provide complete isolation by running their own kernel and hardware virtualization.

You can also use git stash command to stash your changes and then git stash drop to discard the changes.

INPUT:question:
Undoing a git rebase
How do I easily undo a git rebase? A lengthy manual method is:
checkout the commit parent to both of the branches
create and checkout a temporary branch
cherry-pick all commits by hand
reset the faulty rebased branch to point to the temporary branch
In my current situation, this works because I can easily spot commits from both branches (one was my stuff, the other was my colleague's stuff). However, my approach strikes me as suboptimal and error-prone (let's say I had just rebased with two of my own branches).
Clarification: I am talking about a rebase during which multiple commits were replayed, not only one.
OUTPUT:answer:
To easily undo a git rebase, you can use the command "git rebase --abort". This command will stop the current rebase and return your repository to the state it was in before the rebase command was executed. It can also be used to undo a failed rebase. Be aware that any changes made during the rebase will be discarded.

Alternatively, you can use "git reset" to move the branch pointer to the commit before the rebase, effectively undoing the changes made during the rebase. This command can be used in the form "git reset <commit_hash>", where <commit_hash> is the hash of the commit before the rebase. This will also discard any changes made during the rebase.

In both cases, it is highly recommended to make sure that you have committed or stash any changes before running this command.

INPUT:question:
How do I execute a program or call a system command?
How do I call an external command within Python as if I had typed it in a shell or command prompt?
OUTPUT:answer:
There are several ways to execute a program or call a system command in Python, depending on your needs. Here are a few options:

Using the subprocess module: The subprocess module allows you to spawn new processes, connect to their input/output/error pipes, and obtain their return codes. For example, to run the command ls -l and capture the output, you could use the following code:

import subprocess
result = subprocess.run(["ls", "-l"], capture_output=True, text=True)
print(result.stdout)
Using the os module: The os module provides a way to spawn new processes using the os.system() function. For example, to run the command ls -l you could use the following code:

import os
os.system("ls -l")
Using the os.popen() function: The os.popen() function also allows you to spawn new processes and connect to their input/output/error pipes. For example, to run the command ls -l and capture the output, you could use the following code:

import os
output = os.popen("ls -l").read()
print(output)
Note that all the methods above are running the command in synchronously. If you want to run them asynchronously in python you have to use threading or asyncio library.

What are the differences between a HashMap and a Hashtable in Java?
What are the differences between a HashMap and a Hashtable in Java?
Which is more efficient for non-threaded applications?
OUTPUT:answer:
In Java, a HashMap and a Hashtable are both classes that implement the Map interface and provide a hash-table based implementation. However, there are some key differences between the two:

HashMap is non-synchronized, meaning it is not thread-safe. Hashtable is synchronized, meaning it is thread-safe.
HashMap allows null keys and values, while Hashtable does not allow null keys or values.
HashMap is generally considered to be more efficient for non-threaded applications because it is non-synchronized. The synchronization in Hashtable can cause a performance hit in non-threaded environments.
When using a single-threaded application, HashMap is generally the better choice because of its better performance. However, in a multi-threaded environment, Hashtable should be used to ensure that data is not corrupted by multiple threads accessing the same data simultaneously.

INPUT:question:
How do I check out a remote Git branch?
Somebody pushed a branch called test with git push origin test to a shared repository. I can see the branch with git branch -r. How do I check out the remote test branch? I've tried:
git checkout test, which does nothing
git checkout origin/test gives * (no branch)
OUTPUT:answer:
You can check out a remote branch by using the command git checkout -b <local-branch-name> <remote-name>/<remote-branch-name>.

In your case, you can use the command:

git checkout -b test origin/test

This will create a new local branch called "test" and track the remote branch "test" from "origin".

Alternatively, you can also use the command:

git fetch

to get all the branches from remote, and then use the command

git checkout test

to switch to your branch.

INPUT:question:
How do I undo 'git add' before commit?
I mistakenly added files to Git using the command:
git add myfile.txt
I have not yet run git commit. How do I undo this so that these changes will not be included in the commit?
OUTPUT:answer:
You can undo the changes made by 'git add' by using the command:
git reset myfile.txt

This will unstage the file and leave it in the working directory. If you want to undo the changes for multiple files, you can use:
git reset .

This will unstage all the changes made by 'git add' and leave the files in the working directory.

Alternatively, if you want to undo the changes and also discard any changes made to the file in the working directory, you can use:
git reset --hard myfile.txt

This will unstage the file and also discard any changes made to the file in the working directory.

INPUT:question:
Move the most recent commit(s) to a new branch with Git
How do I move my recent commits on master to a new branch, and reset master to before those commits were made? e.g. From this:
master A - B - C - D - E
To this:
newbranch     C - D - E
             /
master A - B
OUTPUT:answer:
You can use the command "git branch newbranch" to create a new branch.
Then use "git reset HEAD3" to reset master to the commit before the most recent 3 commits (HEAD3 means 3 commits before the current commit, in this case commit A)
Then use "git checkout newbranch" to switch to the new branch and "git cherry-pick C D E" to move the commits C, D, and E to the new branch.
And finally, use "git push -u origin newbranch" to push the new branch to the remote repository.

It's always a good idea to make sure you have a backup of your code, or that you are able to revert to a stable commit, before making any changes to your repository.

INPUT:question:
How do I remove local (untracked) files from the current Git working tree?
How do I delete untracked local files from the current working tree?
OUTPUT:answer:
You can use the git clean command to remove untracked files from the current working tree.

Here's the basic usage of the command:

Copy code
git clean -f
The -f or --force option is used to force the removal of files, without the -f option it will only show the files that will be removed but won't remove them.

You can also use the -d or --dir option to remove untracked directories, for example:

Copy code
git clean -df
If you want to remove only certain untracked files, you can specify them as arguments, for example:

Copy code
git clean -f file1.txt file2.txt
This will remove the file1.txt and file2.txt files from the working tree.

Another option is the -n or --dry-run option, it will show what will be removed but it will not remove any files.

Copy code
git clean -n
It's important to note that the git clean command removes files permanently and cannot be undone, so you should be very careful when using it.

If you want to remove all untracked files and directories recursively in all subdirectories, you can use the -x option.

Copy code
git clean -xf
You can also use the .gitignore file to ignore files and directories, so they will not be tracked by git, but they won't be removed from your working tree either.

INPUT:question:
How do I remove a submodule?
How do I remove a Git submodule?
Why can't I do
git submodule rm module_name?
OUTPUT:answer:
To remove a Git submodule, you can use the following command:

git submodule deinit -f -- module_name
git rm -f module_name

The first command git submodule deinit deinitializes the submodule, which removes it from the repository's configuration.
The second command git rm -f removes the submodule from the working tree.

You can't use git submodule rm to remove a submodule because git submodule rm is not a command. The correct command is git submodule deinit and git rm.

Undo a Git merge that hasn't been pushed yet
I accidentally ran git merge some_other_branch on my local master branch. I haven't pushed the changes to origin master. How do I undo the merge?
After merging, git status says:
# On branch master
# Your branch is ahead of 'origin/master' by 5 commits.
How do I undo all these commits?
OUTPUT:answer:
There are a few ways to undo a Git merge that hasn't been pushed yet:

git reset: This command will reset your local master branch to the state of the origin/master branch. You can use the HEAD option to undo the last merge commit.
Copy code
git reset --hard origin/master
git revert: This command will create a new commit that undoes the changes from the merge commit. This is a more "gentle" way of undoing the merge, as it keeps the history of the merge in the repository.
Copy code
git revert -m 1 <merge commit hash>
git revert + git push -f: This is similar to the above, but it will also push the revert commit to the remote repository, effectively undoing the merge on the remote as well. Be careful with this option as it will overwrite the remote branch and it might cause conflicts with other users who already pulled the merge commits.
Copy code
git revert -m 1 <merge commit hash>
git push -f origin master
git branch + git reset + git checkout: This command will create a new branch with the previous state of the master branch, then reset the master branch to the state of the origin/master branch, and then switch to the new branch.
Copy code
git branch new_branch
git reset --hard origin/master
git checkout new_branch
git cherry-pick: If you only want to keep some commits from the merge and discard others, you can use the git cherry-pick command.
Copy code
git cherry-pick <commit hash 1> <commit hash 2> ...
Note that in all the above methods, the commits that were part of the merge will be lost and they cannot be recovered. Be sure to double check that you are undoing the correct merge and that you haven't lost any important work.

INPUT:question:
How do I resolve merge conflicts in a Git repository?
How do I resolve merge conflicts in my Git repository?
OUTPUT:answer:
When merging branches in a Git repository, it's possible that there may be conflicts between the changes made in the different branches. These conflicts will need to be resolved before the merge can be completed. Here are the general steps to resolve merge conflicts in a Git repository:

Start the merge: Use the git merge command to start the merge process. If there are conflicts, Git will indicate which files have conflicts and will not complete the merge.

Open the conflicting files: Open the conflicting files in a text editor to see the specific changes that are causing the conflict. The conflicting changes will be marked with special markers, such as <<<<<<<, |||||||, and >>>>>>>.

Resolve the conflicts: Look at the conflicting changes and decide which changes should be kept and which should be discarded. You can use a visual merge tool to help with this process. Once you have made the necessary changes, save the files.

Commit the resolved conflicts: Once all the conflicts have been resolved, stage the resolved files using git add command, and then commit the changes using git commit.

Continue merging: Repeat the above steps until all conflicts have been resolved and the merge is complete.

INPUT:question:
Why does Google prepend while(1); to their JSON responses?
Why does Google prepend while(1); to their (private) JSON responses?
For example, here's a response while turning a calendar on and off in Google Calendar:
while (1);
[
  ['u', [
    ['smsSentFlag', 'false'],
    ['hideInvitations', 'false'],
    ['remindOnRespondedEventsOnly', 'true'],
    ['hideInvitations_remindOnRespondedEventsOnly', 'false_true'],
    ['Calendar ID stripped for privacy', 'false'],
    ['smsVerifiedFlag', 'true']
  ]]
]
I would assume this is to prevent people from doing an eval() on it, but all you'd really have to do is replace the while and then you'd be set. I would assume the eval prevention is to make sure people write safe JSON parsing code.
I've seen this used in a couple of other places, too, but a lot more so with Google (Mail, Calendar, Contacts, etc.) Strangely enough, Google Docs starts with &&&START&&& instead, and Google Contacts seems to start with while(1); &&&START&&&.
What's going on here?
OUTPUT:answer: The "while(1);" that is prepended to Google's JSON responses is a security measure to protect against a type of attack called "JSON Hijacking." This is a technique where an attacker can use the JavaScript function eval() to execute arbitrary code by using a carefully crafted malicious JSON response. By prepending "while(1);" to the response, the attacker's script will execute the infinite loop and will not have access to the JSON data. It serves as a way of ensuring that the JSON data can only be accessed by authorized scripts and not by malicious ones that might try to use the data for harmful purposes

INPUT:question:
What is a plain English explanation of "Big O" notation?
I'd prefer as little formal definition as possible and simple mathematics.
OUTPUT:answer:
Big O notation is a way to describe the performance of an algorithm or a program. It's a way to measure how well a program can scale as the amount of data it needs to process increases. The "O" stands for "order" or "complexity" and the number that follows it is a way to indicate how quickly the performance of the algorithm or program will degrade as the size of the input data increases.

For example, consider a program that needs to search for an element in an array. If the array is very small, it will take only a few milliseconds for the program to find the element. But if the array is very large, it might take much longer. The Big O notation is used to describe how quickly the program's performance will degrade as the size of the array increases.

There are a few common Big O notations that are used to describe the performance of an algorithm or program:

O(1) means that the program's performance will not degrade at all as the size of the input data increases. This is the best possible performance.
O(n) means that the program's performance will degrade linearly as the size of the input data increases. This is considered to be good performance.
O(n^2) means that the program's performance will degrade exponentially as the size of the input data increases. This is considered to be poor performance.
So, in simple terms, Big O notation is a way to measure how well a program can scale as the amount of data it needs to process increases. It's a way to compare the performance of different algorithms or programs, so you can choose the best one for a given task. O(1) is considered to be best, O(n) is considered to be good, and O(n^2) is considered to be poor.

INPUT:question:
What does if __name__ == "__main__": do?
What does this do, and why should one include the if statement?

For questions where someone simply hasn't called any functions, or incorrectly expects a function named main to be used as an entry point automatically, use Why doesn't the main() function run when I start a Python script? Where does the script start running?.
OUTPUT:answer: The if __name__ == "__main__": block is used to ensure that the code within it will only be executed when the script is run directly, and not when it is imported as a module into another script. When a python script is run, the __name__ variable is set to "__main__" so the code block will be executed. If the script is imported as a module into another script, the __name__ variable will be set to the name of the module, and the code block will not be executed. This idiom is used to create reusable libraries without running the main code when imported.

INPUT:question:
Debug certificate expired" error in Eclipse Android plugins
I am using Eclipse Android plugins to build a project, but I am
getting this error in the console window:
[2010-02-03 10:31:14 - androidVNC]Error generating final archive:
Debug certificate expired on 1/30/10 2:35 PM!
How do I fix it?
OUTPUT:answer:
To fix the "Debug certificate expired" error in Eclipse Android plugins, you need to create a new debug keystore and update the project's settings to use the new keystore.

Here are the steps to create a new debug keystore:

Open the command prompt and navigate to the Java SDK bin directory (e.g. C:\Program Files\Java\jdkx.x.x_xx\bin).
Type the following command: keytool -genkey -v -keystore debug.keystore -storepass android -alias androiddebugkey -keypass android -keyalg RSA -validity 14000.
Press enter and follow the prompts to create the keystore.
Locate the newly created keystore (debug.keystore) in the Java SDK bin directory.
Next, you need to update your project's settings to use the new keystore:

Right-click on your project and select "Properties".
Select "Android" on the left panel.
Under "Signing" select "Use custom debug keystore".
Browse and select the newly created keystore (debug.keystore).
Click OK to save the changes.
Now you should be able to build the project without encountering the "Debug certificate expired" error

INPUT:question:
What is the difference between __str__ and __repr__?
What is the difference between __str__ and __repr__ in Python?
OUTPUT:answer:
In Python, __str__ and __repr__ are both dunder methods used to define human-readable and unambiguous string representations of an object, respectively.

__str__ is meant to return a string that provides a concise, user-friendly representation of an object. The output of __str__ is usually intended for display to end-users, while still being informative enough to give an idea of what the object represents.

__repr__, on the other hand, is intended to provide a unambiguous, complete representation of an object. This representation should be formatted as a string and should ideally be usable as code to recreate the object if passed to eval(). The output of __repr__ is intended for debugging and development purposes.

In summary, __str__ is for a friendly, readable representation and __repr__ is for a unambiguous, complete representation.

C++11 introduced a standardized memory model. What does it mean? And how is it going to affect C++ programming?
C++11 introduced a standardized memory model, but what exactly does that mean? And how is it going to affect C++ programming?
This article (by Gavin Clarke who quotes Herb Sutter) says that,
The memory model means that C++ code
now has a standardized library to call
regardless of who made the compiler
and on what platform it's running.
There's a standard way to control how
different threads talk to the
processor's memory.
"When you are talking about splitting
[code] across different cores that's
in the standard, we are talking about
the memory model. We are going to
optimize it without breaking the
following assumptions people are going
to make in the code," Sutter said.
Well, I can memorize this and similar paragraphs available online (as I've had my own memory model since birth :P) and can even post as an answer to questions asked by others, but to be honest, I don't exactly understand this.
C++ programmers used to develop multi-threaded applications even before, so how does it matter if it's POSIX threads, or Windows threads, or C++11 threads? What are the benefits? I want to understand the low-level details.
I also get this feeling that the C++11 memory model is somehow related to C++11 multi-threading support, as I often see these two together. If it is, how exactly? Why should they be related?
I don't know how the internals of multi-threading work, and what memory model means in general.
OUTPUT:answer:
The C++11 Standardized Memory Model specifies the rules for accessing and modifying the shared data in concurrent programs. It defines how the different threads in a program interact with memory and the order in which memory accesses by different threads should become visible to each other. This is important for ensuring the consistency and predictability of program behavior in multithreaded environments.

The introduction of the standardized memory model in C++11 will affect C++ programming by providing a clear and well-defined framework for writing concurrent programs in C++. This will lead to more consistent and predictable behavior across different platforms and make it easier to write programs that can take advantage of multiple cores and processors. Additionally, it will make it easier to write concurrent code that is portable across different systems and platforms.

css

INPUT:question:
How do I get a consistent byte representation of strings in C# without manually specifying an encoding?
How do I convert a string to a byte[] in .NET (C#) without manually specifying a specific encoding?
I'm going to encrypt the string. I can encrypt it without converting, but I'd still like to know why encoding comes to play here.
Also, why should encoding even be taken into consideration? Can't I simply get what bytes the string has been stored in? Why is there a dependency on character encodings?
OUTPUT:answer:
In .NET, strings are encoded as UTF-16, which means each character in a string is represented by two bytes. When you convert a string to a byte array, you need to specify an encoding to determine how the string should be translated into a byte representation. The choice of encoding can affect the resulting byte array, because different encodings may map the same string to different sequences of bytes.

For example, if you convert a string to a byte array using the UTF-8 encoding, the resulting byte array will be different than if you use the UTF-16 encoding.

When encrypting a string, you should use a consistent encoding to ensure that the same string is always translated to the same sequence of bytes, so that you can properly encrypt and decrypt it. If you don't specify an encoding, .NET will use the default encoding for your system, which may not be what you expect.

It's not possible to simply get the bytes that the string has been stored in, because a string is a higher-level object that is abstracted from the underlying representation of its characters in memory. To convert a string to a byte array, you need to translate the string into a specific representation, such as UTF-8 or UTF-16, using an encoding.

INPUT:question:
What do 'real', 'user' and 'sys' mean in the output of time(1)?
$ time foo
real        0m0.003s
user        0m0.000s
sys         0m0.004s
$
What do real, user and sys mean in the output of time? Which one is meaningful when benchmarking my app?
OUTPUT:answer:
In the output of time, 'real', 'user', and 'sys' represent the following:

'real': The total elapsed time that has passed between starting and finishing the execution of the command, including time spent waiting for resources like I/O.

'user': The amount of CPU time spent executing instructions in user mode.

'sys': The amount of CPU time spent executing instructions in system (kernel) mode.

For benchmarking your app, the 'real' time is usually the most meaningful, as it gives an estimate of the total time that has passed during the execution of the command, including any waiting times.

INPUT:question:
Why shouldn't I use mysql_* functions in PHP?

OUTPUT:answer:
The mysql_* functions in PHP are deprecated and have been removed in PHP 7. They are not recommended for new projects as they are insecure, slow and offer limited features compared to modern database extensions such as PDO or MySQLi. These functions are also prone to SQL injection attacks and do not properly handle escaping user input, which can result in security vulnerabilities.

The reason you may be receiving a "No such file or directory" error is because the extension for these functions has been removed in PHP 7. The error occurs because the mysql_connect() function is not available in your version of PHP.

It's recommended to use either PDO or MySQLi, which provide a more secure and efficient way to interact with databases and offer advanced features such as prepared statements and transaction management.

INPUT:question:
What is the optimal algorithm for the game 2048?
I have recently stumbled upon the game 2048. You merge similar tiles by moving them in any of the four directions to make "bigger" tiles. After each move, a new tile appears at random empty position with a value of either 2 or 4. The game terminates when all the boxes are filled and there are no moves that can merge tiles, or you create a tile with a value of 2048.
One, I need to follow a well-defined strategy to reach the goal. So, I thought of writing a program for it.
My current algorithm:
while (!game_over) {
    for each possible move:
        count_no_of_merges_for_2-tiles and 4-tiles
    choose the move with a large number of merges
}
What I am doing is at any point, I will try to merge the tiles with values 2 and 4, that is, I try to have 2 and 4 tiles, as minimum as possible. If I try it this way, all other tiles were automatically getting merged and the strategy seems good.
But, when I actually use this algorithm, I only get around 4000 points before the game terminates. Maximum points AFAIK is slightly more than 20,000 points which is way larger than my current score. Is there a better algorithm than the above?
OUTPUT:answer:
Your current algorithm is a basic greedy approach, which only focuses on merging 2 and 4 tiles, but it doesn't consider other factors such as tile placement and maximizing the number of empty tiles.

A better approach is to use a Minimax algorithm with alpha-beta pruning. The algorithm simulates all possible moves and evaluates the best move by assigning scores to each possible game state. The score is calculated based on several factors such as tile placement, number of empty tiles, and the sum of tile values.

There are also more sophisticated algorithms such as Monte Carlo Tree Search (MCTS), which can be used to find the optimal strategy. MCTS is a powerful algorithm that has been used to solve complex games such as chess and Go. However, it can be computationally intensive, so you may need to implement it carefully to ensure it runs efficiently for 2048.

How do I calculate someone's age based on a DateTime type birthday?
Given a DateTime representing a person's birthday, how do I calculate their age in years?
OUTPUT:answer:
To calculate someone's age from their birthday represented as a DateTime object, you can subtract the birthday from the current date and then extract the year difference:

python
Copy code
from datetime import datetime

def calculate_age(birthday):
    today = datetime.now()
    age = today.year - birthday.year - ((today.month, today.day) < (birthday.month, birthday.day))
    return age
This code uses the datetime.now() function to get the current date, and then subtracts the year of the birthday from the year of the current date. The second part of the subtraction takes care of the "birthday problem", where a person who was born on December 31st will be considered as one year older if the current date is January 1st of the next year.

INPUT:question:
Commit only part of a file's changes in Git
When I make changes to a file in Git, how can I commit only some of the changes?
For example, how could I commit only 15 lines out of 30 lines that have been changed in a file?
OUTPUT:answer:
To commit only part of a file's changes in Git, you need to "stage" the specific changes that you want to include in the commit. Here's how you can do it:

    Use the "git add -p" command to enter the "patch" mode.
    Review the changes that have been made to the file, and select the changes you want to stage for commit.
    Use the "s" command to stage the change, and the "n" command to skip the change.
    Repeat the process for each change that you want to stage.
    When you're finished, use the "git commit" command to create the commit.

For example, let's say you made 30 changes to a file called "file.txt". To stage only the first 15 changes for commit, you would run the following commands:

csharp

$ git add -p file.txt

Then, in the patch mode:

csharp

$ git add -p

Use the "s" command to stage the first 15 changes, and "n" to skip the rest. Finally:

ruby

$ git commit

OUTPUT:answer:
You can determine the version of PowerShell installed on a computer by using the following command in PowerShell:

bash

This will display the version number, build number, and other information about the installed version of PowerShell. If PowerShell is not installed on the computer, running this command will result in an error.

INPUT:question:
Difference between decimal, float and double in .NET?
What is the difference between decimal, float and double in .NET?
When would someone use one of these?
OUTPUT:answer:
In .NET, decimal, float, and double are data types used to represent numeric values with varying levels of precision and range.

decimal: It is a high-precision floating-point data type with 28-29 significant digits of precision. It is used when precision is required, such as in financial calculations.

float: It is a single-precision floating-point data type with 7 significant digits of precision. It has a smaller range and precision than decimal but is faster for floating-point operations.

double: It is a double-precision floating-point data type with 15-16 significant digits of precision. It has a larger range and precision than float but is slower for floating-point operations.

In general, you would choose decimal for financial calculations that require high precision, float for single-precision floating-point operations, and double for double-precision floating-point operations

INPUT:question:
How to decide when to use Node.js?
I am new to this kind of stuff, but lately I've been hearing a lot about how good Node.js is. Considering how much I love working with jQuery and JavaScript in general, I can't help but wonder how to decide when to use Node.js. The web application I have in mind is something like Bitly - takes some content, archives it. 
From all the homework I have been doing in the last few days, I obtained the following information. Node.js 
is a command-line tool that can be run as a regular web server and lets one run JavaScript programs
utilizes the great V8 JavaScript engine
is very good when you need to do several things at the same time
is event-based so all the wonderful Ajax-like stuff can be done on the server side
lets us share code between the browser and the backend
lets us talk with MySQL
Some of the sources that I have come across are:
Diving into Node.js – Introduction and Installation
Understanding NodeJS
Node by Example (Archive.is)
Let’s Make a Web App: NodePad
Considering that Node.js can be run almost out-of-the-box on Amazon's EC2 instances, I am trying to understand what type of problems require Node.js as opposed to any of the mighty kings out there like PHP, Python and Ruby. I understand that it really depends on the expertise one has on a language, but my question falls more into the general category of: When to use a particular framework and what type of problems is it particularly suited for?
OUTPUT:answer:
Node.js is a platform for building fast, scalable network applications in JavaScript. It's event-driven, non-blocking I/O model makes it well-suited for real-time, data-intensive applications. Some use cases for Node.js include:

Web applications with real-time updates (e.g. chat applications)
Streaming data-intensive services (e.g. video and audio streaming)
RESTful APIs
Command-line tools and utilities
It's important to note that Node.js is not the best choice for every type of application. For example, it may not be the best choice for CPU-intensive applications or applications with complex server-side logic. In general, it's best to use Node.js when you need a fast and efficient solution for building network applications, and when you are comfortable with JavaScript.

If you have already set the display_errors directive to 1 in your php.ini file and the error reporting level to E_ALL, and you've restarted your Apache web server, then the following common issues might cause your PHP errors to not display:

Errors are being logged to a different location. You can check the location of your PHP error log by checking the error_log directive in your php.ini file.

Your code might have a syntax error in a portion that is not included by your PHP script, such as an include file, or a file specified by an auto-prepend file directive.

You may have an output buffer enabled which is preventing errors from being displayed. You can use ob_end_flush() to clear any existing output buffers and see your errors.

Some hosts may have their own custom PHP error handler that is suppressing the display of errors. In this case, you should contact your hosting provider for more information.

INPUT:question:
Java inner class and static nested class
What is the main difference between an inner class and a static nested class in Java? Does design / implementation play a role in choosing one of these?
OUTPUT:answer:
In Java, the main difference between an inner class and a static nested class is the way they are associated with the enclosing class.

An inner class is a non-static nested class that has access to the instance variables and methods of its enclosing class. It can be declared within the body of the enclosing class and is often used as a way to logically group classes that are only used in the context of the enclosing class.

A static nested class is a nested class that is declared with the static keyword. Unlike an inner class, it does not have access to the instance variables and methods of its enclosing class. It can be used as a regular class and is often used as a way to logically group related classes.

Design and implementation do play a role in choosing between an inner class and a static nested class. The choice between the two often depends on how tightly the class is coupled to the enclosing class. If the class is tightly coupled and needs access to the instance variables and methods of the enclosing class, an inner class may be the best choice. If the class is more loosely coupled and does not need access to the enclosing class, a static nested class may be a better choice.

When should I use double or single quotes in JavaScript?
console.log("double"); vs. console.log('single');
I see more and more JavaScript libraries out there using single quotes when handling strings. What are the reasons to use one over the other?
I thought they're pretty much interchangeable.
OUTPUT:answer:
Both double quotes (") and single quotes (') are interchangeable in JavaScript and can be used to define strings. However, the general convention in JavaScript is to use single quotes ('), while double quotes (") are used to define string values within single-quoted strings.

For example:
console.log('I am a string defined with single quotes');
console.log('I am a string defined with single quotes, but I contain a "double-quoted" string value.')
Ultimately, the choice between single and double quotes is a matter of personal preference or the specific style guide your team follows. Just make sure to be consistent within your codebase.

INPUT:question:
How to change the commit author for a single commit?
I want to change the author of one specific commit in the history. It's not the latest commit.
Related: How do I change the author and committer name/email for multiple commits?
OUTPUT:answer:
You can change the author of a single commit using git rebase in interactive mode. Here are the steps:

Run git rebase -i HEAD~<number of commits>, where <number of commits> is the number of commits in your branch starting from the latest one, including the one you want to change.
In the text editor that opens, find the line of the commit you want to change and replace "pick" with "edit".
Save and exit the editor.
Run git commit --amend --author='New Author Name <new.author@email.com>'.
Run git rebase --continue.
Note: Changing a commit in Git history is not recommended, as it can cause problems with any existing branches or pull requests that have already been based on the previous commit.

OUTPUT:answer:
You can create an HTML button that acts like a link by using the "button" element and giving it an "onclick" attribute that triggers a JavaScript function to redirect the user to another page. Here's an example:

php
Copy code
<button onclick="location.href='https://example.com'">Click Me</button>
In this example, when the button is clicked, it will redirect the user to "https://example.com".

This approach is accessible and requires minimal extra characters or parameters in the URL, which makes it a good option for creating buttons that act like links.

INPUT:question:
How does database indexing work?
Given that indexing is so important as your data set increases in size, can someone explain how indexing works at a database-agnostic level?
For information on queries to index a field, check out How do I index a database column.
OUTPUT:answer:
Indexing in databases is a technique that allows for faster data retrieval operations on a database table by creating a separate data structure (the index) that stores a mapping of values in the indexed columns to their corresponding rows in the table. When a query is executed, the database first looks in the index rather than scanning the entire table, reducing the amount of data that needs to be processed.

The basic idea behind indexing is to provide a search tree-like data structure that allows for efficient searching of the data. The most common index structure used in databases is the B-Tree, which provides logarithmic time complexity for most operations. Other index structures such as Hash Tables or Tries can also be used depending on the use case.

When a new record is inserted or an existing record is updated, the index must also be updated to reflect the changes in the underlying data. The cost of maintaining the index needs to be balanced against the benefits of faster query performance.

In summary, indexing in databases is a technique used to increase the performance of data retrieval operations by creating a separate data structure that maps values in the indexed columns to their corresponding rows in the table. This allows the database to search the data more efficiently, reducing the amount of data that needs to be processed.

INPUT:question:
How to copy files from host to Docker container?
I am trying to build a backup and restore solution for the Docker containers that we work with.
I have Docker base image that I have created, ubuntu:base, and do not want have to rebuild it each time with a Docker file to add files to it.
I want to create a script that runs from the host machine and creates a new container using the ubuntu:base Docker image and then copies files into that container.
How can I copy files from the host to the container?
OUTPUT:answer:
You can use the docker cp command to copy files from host to a Docker container. The syntax is as follows:
docker cp <host-src-path> <container-name>:<container-dest-path>
For example, to copy a file file.txt from the host to a container named container_1 in the /tmp directory inside the container, you can run:
docker cp file.txt container_1:/tmp/
You can also copy entire directories by using the -r (recursive) flag:
docker cp -r <host-src-directory> <container-name>:<container-dest-path>
For example, to copy a directory my_dir from the host to a container named container_1 in the /tmp directory inside the container, you can run:
docker cp -r my_dir container_1:/tmp/

OUTPUT:answer:
Yes, the recommended way to test for the existence of a key in a dictionary is to simply use the in operator with the dictionary itself, rather than calling keys() on the dictionary and checking for the presence of the key in the resulting list:

python

  print "blah"
else:
  print "boo"
This method is more concise, readable, and efficient, as it avoids the overhead of constructing the list of keys.

How can I check if a program exists from a Bash script?
How would I validate that a program exists, in a way that will either return an error and exit, or continue with the script?
It seems like it should be easy, but it's been stumping me.
OUTPUT:answer:
In Bash, you can check if a program exists by using the command command with the -v option.

For example:

bash
Copy code
#!/bin/bash

if command -v program_name > /dev/null 2>&1; then
  echo "program_name found, continuing with script"
else
  echo "program_name not found, exiting script"
  exit 1
fi
In this example, command -v program_name returns the path to the program if it exists in the PATH, and returns a non-zero exit status otherwise. The output of the command is redirected to /dev/null so it won't be displayed. The 2>&1 redirects stderr to stdout, which is redirected to /dev/null, so that any error messages produced by the command command are suppressed.

How do I clone a specific Git branch?
Git clone will clone remote branch into local.
Is there any way to clone a specific branch by myself without switching branches on the remote repository?
OUTPUT:answer:
Yes, you can clone a specific Git branch by specifying the branch name after the repository URL. Here's the syntax:
git clone -b <branch> <repository URL>
For example, to clone the "develop" branch of a remote repository located at https://github.com/user/repo.git:
git clone -b develop https://github.com/user/repo.git
This will clone only the specified branch and checkout to the branch directly.

sql

How to do case insensitive search in Vim

but it doesn't work.  I know that in Perl, if I give the i flag into a regex it will turn the regex into a case-insensitive regex. It seems that Vim  has its own way to indicate a case-insensitive regex.
OUTPUT:answer:
To perform a case-insensitive search in Vim, you can add the \c (or \C for case-sensitive search) flag at the end of your search pattern. So in your example, to search for "COPYRIGHT" in a case-insensitive manner, you can use the following command:

INPUT:question:
What does cherry-picking a commit with Git mean?
What does git cherry-pick <commit> do?
OUTPUT:answer:
Git cherry-pick is a Git command that allows you to apply the changes from a specific commit in your current branch. It means to select a single commit from a branch and apply it to another branch. This is useful when you want to bring specific changes from one branch to another branch, without merging the entire branch.

The syntax for cherry-picking a commit in Git is:

php

git cherry-pick <commit>

Where <commit> is the identifier of the commit you want to cherry-pick. The changes made in the specified commit will be applied to the current branch and a new commit will be created in the current branch, reflecting the cherry-picked changes.

>>> for i in range(4): print('.')
.
.
.
.
>>> print('.', '.', '.', '.')
. . . .
Either a newline or a space is added between each value. How can I avoid that, so that the output is .... instead? In other words, how can I "append" strings to the standard output stream?
OUTPUT:answer:
You can use the end parameter of the print function to specify the string that should be used to end the line, instead of the default \n newline character. The end parameter takes a string as its argument. By setting end to an empty string, you can prevent the newline character from being printed:

lua
Copy code
for i in range(4):
    print('.', end='')

print('.', '.', '.', '.', sep='', end='')
The output will be:

Copy code
....

INPUT:question:
Remove file from latest commit
How do I remove a file from the latest commit?
OUTPUT:answer:
Remove File from Commit


tousiqjanjua@gmail.com
Remove file from latest commit
How do I remove a file from the latest commit?

You can use the command git reset to remove a file from the latest commit. Here are the steps:

Use git log to get the hash of the latest commit.
Run git reset <hash> to "reset" the repository to the latest commit, removing all changes in the working directory.
Use git rm <file> to delete the file from both the working directory and the repository's index.
Run git commit -m "Removed <file> from latest commit" to create a new commit without the deleted file.
Alternatively, you can use git revert to "undo" the latest commit and create a new commit with the desired changes. Here are the steps:

Use git log to get the hash of the latest commit.
Run git revert <hash> to revert the changes made in the latest commit and create a new commit.
Use git rm <file> to delete the file from both the working directory and the repository's index.
Run git commit -m "Removed <file> from latest commit" to create a final commit without the deleted file.

INPUT:question:
How do I split a string on a delimiter in Bash?
I have this string stored in a variable:
IN="bla@some.com;john@home.com"
Now I would like to split the strings by ; delimiter so that I have:
ADDR1="bla@some.com"
ADDR2="john@home.com"
I don't necessarily need the ADDR1 and ADDR2 variables. If they are elements of an array that's even better.
After suggestions from the answers below, I ended up with the following which is what I was after:
#!/usr/bin/env bash
IN="bla@some.com;john@home.com"
mails=$(echo $IN | tr ";" "\n")
for addr in $mails
do
    echo "> [$addr]"
done
Output:
> [bla@some.com]
> [john@home.com]
There was a solution involving setting Internal_field_separator (IFS) to ;. I am not sure what happened with that answer, how do you reset IFS back to default?
RE: IFS solution, I tried this and it works, I keep the old IFS and then restore it:
IN="bla@some.com;john@home.com"
OIFS=$IFS
IFS=';'
mails2=$IN
for x in $mails2
do
    echo "> [$x]"
done
IFS=$OIFS
BTW, when I tried 
mails2=($IN)
I only got the first string when printing it in loop, without brackets around $IN it works.
OUTPUT:answer:
To split a string in Bash using a delimiter, you can use the IFS (Internal Field Separator) variable, as follows:

bash

IN="bla@some.com;john@home.com"
IFS=';'
mails2=($IN)
for x in "${mails2[@]}"; do
  echo "> [$x]"
done

The output of the code above will be:

java

> [bla@some.com]
> [john@home.com]

To reset IFS back to its default value, you can simply reassign it to its original value, as follows:

bash

IFS=$OIFS

Where $OIFS is the original value of IFS before it was changed.

In Objective-C, "atomic" and "nonatomic" are used as attributes in the property declarations of a class to control the behavior of the generated accessor methods for the property.

"atomic" properties guarantee that access to the property value is thread-safe and will not result in data corruption by ensuring that access to the property value is done in a way that prevents multiple threads from simultaneously reading or writing to it.
"nonatomic" properties, on the other hand, do not make any guarantees about thread safety, and multiple threads may access the property value simultaneously, potentially resulting in data corruption.
When "atomic" is not specified, the default behavior is "atomic".

So, in your examples:

"@property(nonatomic, retain) UITextField *userName;" creates a "nonatomic" property.
"@property(atomic, retain) UITextField *userName;" creates an "atomic" property.
"@property(retain) UITextField *userName;" creates an "atomic" property since "atomic" is the default behavior.

INPUT:question:
How do I profile C++ code running on Linux?
How do I find areas of my code that run slowly in a C++ application running on Linux?
OUTPUT:answer:
There are several tools that can help you profile C++ code running on Linux:

    gprof: A standard Unix tool for profiling code that reports function-level information about how much time was spent in each function and how many times it was called.

    perf: A Linux performance analysis tool that provides performance metrics for hardware events such as CPU cycles and cache misses, as well as software events such as context switches and page faults.

    Valgrind: A dynamic analysis tool that can be used to find memory leaks, invalid memory accesses, and other problems in C++ programs.

    Callgrind: A tool that is part of the Valgrind suite that provides function-level information about how many times each function was called, how much time was spent in each function, and how many cache misses were incurred.

    gdb: A debugger that can be used to monitor the execution of a program and to identify the source of performance problems.

    Visual Studio Code: A popular open-source code editor that has a C++ profiling tool.

You can use these tools to identify performance bottlenecks in your code, such as functions that are taking too much time to execute, or areas of the code where you are using too much memory.

I've been told not to use for...in with arrays in JavaScript. Why not?
OUTPUT:answer:
for...in is not intended for use with arrays in JavaScript. for...in loops are meant for enumerating the properties of an object, and will include properties that have been added to the object's prototype.

When used with an array, a for...in loop will enumerate all enumerable properties of the array, including any properties that have been added to the Array.prototype object. This can lead to unexpected behavior, as the loop may include properties that you didn't intend to include, or that are not actually part of the array.

For array iteration, it is recommended to use a for loop or forEach method instead. These methods allow you to iterate over the actual elements in the array, rather than any properties that have been added to the prototype.

So the current state is now:
Branches (local and remote)
master
bug-fix-a
bug-fix-b
origin/master
origin/bug-fix-c
Now I would like to call some command to delete branches (in this case bug-fix-a, bug-fix-b), which are no longer represented in the remote repository.
It would be something like the existing command git remote prune origin, but more like git local prune origin.
OUTPUT:answer: You can use the command git remote prune origin. This will remove all local tracking branches that no longer exist on the remote origin. Note that this will only remove the tracking information, not the actual branches. To remove the branches, you'll need to use git branch -d followed by the branch name.

HTTP GET with request body
I'm developing a new RESTful webservice for our application.
When doing a GET on certain entities, clients can request the contents of the entity.
If they want to add some parameters (for example sorting a list) they can add these parameters in the query string.
Alternatively I want people to be able to specify these parameters in the request body.
HTTP/1.1 does not seem to explicitly forbid this. This will allow them to specify more information, might make it easier to specify complex XML requests.
My questions:
Is this a good idea altogether?
Will HTTP clients have issues with using request bodies within a GET request?
https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2616
OUTPUT:answer:
No, it is not a good idea to include a request body in an HTTP GET request. The HTTP specification (RFC 2616) defines the GET method as a safe and idempotent method, which means it should only be used to retrieve information and should have no side-effects. Including a request body in a GET request goes against this principle and can cause compatibility issues with clients that conform to the HTTP specification.

It is generally recommended to use query parameters in the URL to specify additional information for a GET request. If the information to be sent is too complex or too large to fit into query parameters, it is better to use a POST or PUT request instead.

lua

find . -name "*.txt"

This command will search for all files with a .txt extension in the current directory and its subdirectories.

bash

INPUT:question:
Why is char[] preferred over String for passwords?
In Swing, the password field has a getPassword() (returns char[]) method instead of the usual getText() (returns String) method. Similarly, I have come across a suggestion not to use String to handle passwords.
Why does String pose a threat to security when it comes to passwords?
It feels inconvenient to use char[].
OUTPUT:answer:
Strings are immutable in Java and once created, they cannot be changed. This means that when you perform operations on a String, it creates a new String object in memory, while the original one remains unchanged. If a password is stored in a String, it remains in memory until garbage collection reclaims the memory. This increases the risk of the password being exposed, as it can be accessed by an attacker who gains access to the memory dump.

On the other hand, char arrays can be easily wiped out of memory after use, which makes them a safer option for storing passwords. The getPassword() method returns a char array, allowing the password to be cleared from memory after use, reducing the risk of exposure.

While using char[] might feel inconvenient, it is a recommended security measure to protect sensitive information like passwords.

INPUT:question:
Using global variables in a function
How do I create or use a global variable inside a function?
How do I use a global variable that was defined in one function inside other functions?
Failing to use the global keyword where appropriate often causes UnboundLocalError. The precise rules for this are explained at UnboundLocalError on local variable when reassigned after first use. Generally, please close other questions as a duplicate of that question when an explanation is sought, and this question when someone simply needs to know the global keyword.
OUTPUT:answer:
To use a global variable inside a function, you need to use the "global" keyword before the variable. This tells Python that the variable is a global variable and can be used across different functions. Here's an example:

python

# Define a global variable
x = 10

def my_function():
    global x
    x += 1
    print(x)

# Call the function
my_function() # Output: 11

# The global variable has been changed by the function
print(x) # Output: 11

To use a global variable that was defined in one function inside other functions, you need to use the "global" keyword in each function that wants to access the global variable:

python

# Define a global variable
x = 10

def first_function():
    global x
    x += 1

def second_function():
    global x
    x += 2

# Call both functions
first_function()
second_function()

# The global variable has been changed by both functions
print(x) # Output: 13

INPUT:question:
How does data binding work in AngularJS?
How does data binding work in the AngularJS framework?
I haven't found technical details on their site. It's more or less clear how it works when data is propagated from view to model. But how does AngularJS track changes of model properties without setters and getters?
I found that there are JavaScript watchers that may do this work. But they are not supported in Internet Explorer 6 and Internet Explorer 7. So how does AngularJS know that I changed for example the following and reflected this change on a view?
myobject.myproperty="new value";
OUTPUT:answer:
In AngularJS, data binding is achieved through a combination of dirty checking and digest cycles. When a model property is changed, AngularJS adds the property to a "dirty" checking list and runs a digest cycle to see if any changes have been made. The digest cycle runs until all model properties have stabilized and there are no more changes to be made. This process is repeated continuously to ensure that the view and model are always in sync.

AngularJS uses JavaScript getters and setters to track changes to model properties. In modern browsers, these getters and setters are automatically generated for object properties, but in older browsers such as Internet Explorer 6 and 7, AngularJS uses a fallback method based on AngularJS' own implementation of getters and setters, known as "accessors." These accessors are not subject to the same limitations as the native getters and setters, and thus AngularJS can continue to track changes to model properties even in older browsers.

CSS triangles work by setting the width and height of an element to 0 and creating transparent borders along two sides, while the third side is given a solid color border. This creates an illusion of a triangle by revealing only the color of the third border, and hiding the other two sides.

In the example, the triangle is facing upwards and has a width of 100px (the sum of the two 50px wide transparent borders), a height of 100px (the height of the red border), and is colored red. The border-bottom property creates the solid red border, while the border-left and border-right properties create the transparent borders.

INPUT:question:
How do I recover a dropped stash in Git?
I frequently use git stash and git stash pop to save and restore changes in my working tree. Yesterday, I had some changes in my working tree that I had stashed and popped, and then I made more changes to my working tree. I'd like to go back and review yesterday's stashed changes, but git stash pop appears to remove all references to the associated commit.
I know that if I use git stash then .git/refs/stash contains the reference of the commit used to create the stash. And .git/logs/refs/stash contains the whole stash. But those references are gone after git stash pop. I know that the commit is still in my repository somewhere, but I don't know what it was.
Is there an easy way to recover yesterday's stash commit reference?
OUTPUT:answer:
You can recover a dropped stash by using the command git reflog to show a list of all recent reference updates in your repository, including stash entries. You can find the stash entry you're looking for by checking the stash list and the stash apply events. You can then apply the stash with the command git stash apply <stash_reference>.

Example:

php

git reflog
<reflog entries>
<stash@{0}: WIP on <branch>: <commit message>
<stash@{1}: WIP on <branch>: <commit message>
...

In this example, you can recover the stash by using the reference stash@{0}. You can apply the stash with git stash apply stash@{0}.

Why can templates only be implemented in the header file?
Quote from The C++ standard library: a tutorial and handbook:
  The only portable way of using templates at the moment is to implement them in header files by using inline functions.
Why is this?
(Clarification: header files are not the only portable solution. But they are the most convenient portable solution.)
OUTPUT:answer: The reason templates are typically implemented in header files is because they are compiled as part of the program that uses them, not as a separate object file like normal functions. The implementation of the template must be visible to the compiler at the point of instantiation, which occurs in the source file that uses the template. By including the implementation in a header file and including the header file in the source file, the compiler has access to the implementation at the point of instantiation. This makes it possible to instantiate the template for different types, generating different versions of the same code.
