OUTPUT:answer:
You can view local, unpushed commits using the command git log origin/<branch_name>..HEAD. Replace <branch_name> with the name of the branch you are working on. This command will display the log of all the commits on your local branch that haven't been pushed to the remote repository.

As for why git status doesn't always display the number of ahead commits, it is because git status only displays information about changes to tracked files in the repository, not about the difference between your local branch and the remote branch.

INPUT:question:
How do I clone a list so that it doesn't change unexpectedly after assignment?
While using new_list = my_list, any modifications to new_list changes my_list every time. Why is this, and how can I clone or copy the list to prevent it?
OUTPUT:answer:
In Python, when you assign a list to a new variable using "new_list = my_list", both variables refer to the same list object in memory. Any modifications made to the list using either variable will affect both references.

To create a copy of the list that is independent of the original, you can use the copy module's copy function, or the list's slicing syntax with no arguments, like this:

go

import copy
new_list = copy.copy(my_list)

or

new_list = my_list[:]

This creates a new list object in memory that contains the same elements as the original list. Any modifications made to this new list will not affect the original list.

In this example, '%b %d %Y %I:%M%p' is the format string that specifies the pattern of the input string. The format codes used in the string are:

%b: abbreviated month name

%I: hour (12-hour clock)
%M: minute
%p: AM/PM

INPUT:question:
Deep cloning objects
I want to do something like:
MyObject myObj = GetMyObj(); // Create and fill a new object
MyObject newObj = myObj.Clone();
And then make changes to the new object that are not reflected in the original object.
I don't often need this functionality, so when it's been necessary, I've resorted to creating a new object and then copying each property individually, but it always leaves me with the feeling that there is a better or more elegant way of handling the situation.
How can I clone or deep copy an object so that the cloned object can be modified without any changes being reflected in the original object?
OUTPUT:answer:
To deep clone an object in C#, you can use the System.Object.MemberwiseClone() method, which creates a shallow copy of the object. However, this method only creates a shallow copy, meaning that any reference type fields will still refer to the same object instances as the original object.

To create a true deep copy, you can implement a custom deep clone method by manually copying each field, including reference type fields, to a new object. Alternatively, you can use a serialization technique, such as BinaryFormatter or JsonSerializer, to serialize the original object to a memory stream, and then deserialize the memory stream to a new object, effectively creating a deep copy.

Find (and kill) process locking port 3000 on Mac
How do I find (and kill) processes that listen to/use my TCP ports? I'm on macOS.
Sometimes, after a crash or some bug, my Rails app is locking port 3000. I can't find it using ps -ef...
When running
rails server
I get
Address already in use - bind(2) (Errno::EADDRINUSE)
The same issue happens when stopping Node.js process. Even after the process is stopped and the app stops running, port 3000 is locked. When starting the app again, getting
Address already in use (Errno::EADDRINUSE)
OUTPUT:answer:
To find the process locking port 3000 on macOS, you can run the following command in your terminal:

css

lsof -i tcp:3000

This will list all the open files and the process IDs (PIDs) that are using port 3000. To kill the process, you can use the kill command followed by the PID:

bash

kill <pid>

Replace <pid> with the actual PID of the process you want to kill.

For example:

shell

$ lsof -i tcp:3000
COMMAND   PID   USER   FD   TYPE             DEVICE SIZE/OFF NODE NAME
node    12345 yourusername    4u  IPv4 0xffffff8032abcd12      0t0  TCP *:3000 (LISTEN)

$ kill 12345

INPUT:question:
Why is "1000000000000000 in range(1000000000000001)" so fast in Python 3?
It is my understanding that the range() function, which is actually an object type in Python 3, generates its contents on the fly, similar to a generator.
This being the case, I would have expected the following line to take an inordinate amount of time because, in order to determine whether 1 quadrillion is in the range, a quadrillion values would have to be generated:
1_000_000_000_000_000 in range(1_000_000_000_000_001)
Furthermore: it seems that no matter how many zeroes I add on, the calculation more or less takes the same amount of time (basically instantaneous).
I have also tried things like this, but the calculation is still almost instant:
# count by tens
1_000_000_000_000_000_000_000 in range(0,1_000_000_000_000_000_000_001,10)
If I try to implement my own range function, the result is not so nice!
def my_crappy_range(N):
    i = 0
    while i < N:
        yield i
        i += 1
    return
What is the range() object doing under the hood that makes it so fast?
Martijn Pieters's answer was chosen for its completeness, but also see abarnert's first answer for a good discussion of what it means for range to be a full-fledged sequence in Python 3, and some information/warning regarding potential inconsistency for __contains__ function optimization across Python implementations. abarnert's other answer goes into some more detail and provides links for those interested in the history behind the optimization in Python 3 (and lack of optimization of xrange in Python 2). Answers by poke and by wim provide the relevant C source code and explanations for those who are interested.
OUTPUT:answer: In Python 3, the range function is optimized and implemented as an object of range type, which is a full-fledged sequence that implements an efficient __contains__ method. This method uses a binary search algorithm to check if a value is in the range, making it much faster than generating all the values in the range and checking one by one. The optimization makes the in operator with a range object very fast, even for large ranges. The behavior of the range object in Python 3 is not consistent across Python implementations, and the optimization may not be present in all implementations.

INPUT:question:
Docker: Copying files from Docker container to host
I'm thinking of using Docker to build my dependencies on a Continuous Integration (CI) server, so that I don't have to install all the runtimes and libraries on the agents themselves. 
To achieve this I would need to copy the build artifacts that are built inside the container back into the host. Is that possible?
OUTPUT:answer:
Yes, it is possible to copy files from a Docker container to the host. One way to do this is to use the docker cp command. For example:

php

docker cp <container_id>:<source_path> <destination_path>

You can also mount a host directory as a volume in the container, so that any changes made to the files in the volume are persisted on the host file system. To mount a host directory as a volume in a container, you can use the -v or --volume option with the docker run command. For example:

php

docker run -v <host_path>:<container_path> <image>

go

In this example, /path/to/source/file is the source file that you want to copy, and /path/to/destination/file is the location where you want to copy the file to. INPUT:question:
How to mkdir only if a directory does not already exist?
I am writing a shell script to run under the KornShell (ksh) on AIX. I would like to use the mkdir command to create a directory. But the directory may already exist, in which case I do not want to do anything. So I want to either test to see that the directory does not exist, or suppress the "File exists" error that mkdir throws when it tries to create an existing directory. 
How can I best do this?
OUTPUT:answer:
In the KornShell (ksh) on AIX, you can use the following syntax to create a directory only if it does not already exist:

bash

mkdir -p /path/to/directory
The -p option tells mkdir to create the parent directories if they do not exist, and to do nothing if the specified directory already exists. This means that you won't get an error message if you try to create a directory that already exists. The mkdir command will return a success exit code (0) in both cases, whether the directory was created or it already existed.

INPUT:question:
What is JSONP, and why was it created?
I understand JSON, but not JSONP. Wikipedia's document on JSON is (was) the top search result for JSONP. It says this:
  JSONP or "JSON with padding" is a JSON extension wherein a prefix is specified as an input argument of the call itself.
Huh? What call? That doesn't make any sense to me. JSON is a data format. There's no call.
The 2nd search result is from some guy named Remy, who writes this about JSONP:
  JSONP is script tag injection, passing the response from the server in to a user specified function.
I can sort of understand that, but it's still not making any sense.
So what is JSONP? Why was it created (what problem does it solve)? And why would I use it? 
Addendum: I've just created a new page for JSONP on Wikipedia; it now has a clear and thorough description of JSONP, based on jvenema's answer.
OUTPUT:answer:
JSONP (JSON with Padding) is a technique for overcoming the same-origin policy limitations of web browsers, which prevent a web page from making requests to a different domain than the one the web page originated from.

JSONP works by wrapping the JSON data in a function call, and then returning the data to the web page as a script file. The web page specifies the function name to be called in the URL of the JSONP request. When the server returns the JSON data wrapped in the specified function, the browser executes the function and passes the JSON data as an argument.

JSONP was created as a workaround to allow communication between domains, when the same-origin policy was preventing regular AJAX (XMLHttpRequest) requests. JSONP was widely used in the early days of the web, before the introduction of CORS (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing), which provides a standard way for a web page to make requests to a different domain.

You would use JSONP in situations where you need to make a request to a server in a different domain, and CORS is not supported or is not a suitable solution. JSONP can be a simple and effective solution, but it has some limitations and security concerns, so it's not always the best choice.

How do I modify a specific commit?
I have the following commit history:
HEAD
HEAD~
HEAD~2
HEAD~3
git commit --amend modifies the current HEAD commit. But how do I modify HEAD~3?
OUTPUT:answer:
To modify an older commit, you need to first "checkout" the commit you want to change using git checkout <commit-hash>. Replace <commit-hash> with the hash of the commit you want to modify.

Once you are on that commit, you can use git reset --soft HEAD~ to reset the branch to the previous commit, keeping the changes in the index. Then you can make the desired changes and use git commit --amend to create a new commit with the updated changes.

After that, you need to use git cherry-pick <new-commit-hash> to apply the changes from the new commit to the branch you were originally on. Replace <new-commit-hash> with the hash of the new commit.

Note: This process can cause conflicts if changes have been made to the code in the meantime, so make sure to backup your code before proceeding.

INPUT:question:
Make the current Git branch a master branch
I have a repository in Git. I made a branch, then did some changes both to the master and to the branch.
Then, tens of commits later, I realized the branch is in much better state than the master, so I want the branch to "become" the master and disregard the changes on master.
I cannot merge it, because I don't want to keep the changes on master. What should I do?
Extra: In this case, the 'old' master has already been push-ed to another repository such as GitHub. How does this change things?
OUTPUT:answer:
You can reset the master branch to the state of the branch, and then force push to update the remote repository.
Here are the steps to do it:

    Checkout the branch that you want to be the new master: git checkout my-branch
    Reset the master branch to the state of the current branch: git branch -f master my-branch
    Force push the master branch to the remote repository: git push -f origin master

Note: The force push will overwrite the remote repository's master branch with your local version, so make sure to coordinate with other people who may be working on the same repository.

INPUT:question:
How do I delete all Git branches which have been merged?
How do I delete branches which have already been merged? Can I delete them all at once, instead of deleting each branch one-by-one?
OUTPUT:answer:
You can delete all branches that have been merged by using the following Git command:

perl

$ git branch --merged | grep -v "\*" | xargs -n 1 git branch -d

This command lists all branches that have been merged and deletes them one by one. The grep -v "\*" part is used to exclude the currently checked-out branch from the list.

INPUT:question:
Class (static) variables and methods
How do I create class (i.e. static) variables or methods in Python?

What are drawbacks or disadvantages of singleton pattern?
The singleton pattern is a fully paid up member of the GoF's patterns book, but it lately seems rather orphaned by the developer world. I still use quite a lot of singletons, especially for factory classes, and while you have to be a bit careful about multithreading issues (like any class actually), I fail to see why they are so awful.
Stack Overflow especially seems to assume that everyone agrees that Singletons are evil. Why?
Please support your answers with "facts, references, or specific expertise"
OUTPUT:answer:
There are several drawbacks or disadvantages of using the singleton pattern:

    Global State: Singletons introduce global state into your application, making it harder to reason about the flow of data and state changes. This can lead to tight coupling between objects, making it harder to maintain and test your code.

    Testing difficulties: Singletons can be difficult to test, as they are tightly coupled to the rest of the application and cannot be easily substituted with mock objects. This can lead to slow, difficult-to-maintain test suites.

    Dependency Injection: Singletons can be seen as an anti-pattern when used in conjunction with dependency injection, as they undermine the entire purpose of dependency injection, which is to achieve loose coupling between objects.

    Tight coupling: Singletons can lead to tight coupling between objects, making it harder to maintain and test your code.

    Hard to subclass: Singletons can be difficult to subclass, as they often have complex, global state that cannot be easily changed or extended.

These are some of the main criticisms of the singleton pattern. However, it's worth noting that, like any design pattern, singletons have their place in certain situations, such as when a single instance of a class is required to coordinate actions across the system. The key is to be mindful of their limitations and use them appropriately.

INPUT:question:
What is the difference between public, protected, package-private and private in Java?
In Java, are there clear rules on when to use each of access modifiers, namely the default (package private), public, protected and private, while making class and interface and dealing with inheritance?
OUTPUT:answer:
The access modifiers in Java determine the visibility and accessibility of class members (fields, methods, and inner classes) to other parts of the program.

    private: Only accessible within the same class.
    package-private (default): Accessible within the same package but not from outside it.
    protected: Accessible within the same class and its subclasses, as well as within the same package.
    public: Accessible from anywhere in the program.

As for the clear rules on when to use each access modifier, it is generally a matter of design choice based on the desired level of encapsulation and abstraction. A common rule of thumb is to use the least restrictive access level necessary, i.e., to use private whenever possible and only use higher access levels if required by a specific use case.

INPUT:question:
What is the difference between the 'COPY' and 'ADD' commands in a Dockerfile?
What is the difference between the COPY and ADD commands in a Dockerfile, and when would I use one over the other?
COPY <src> <dest>
  The COPY instruction will copy new files from <src> and add them to the container's filesystem at path <dest>
ADD <src> <dest>
  The ADD instruction will copy new files from <src> and add them to the container's filesystem at path <dest>.
OUTPUT:answer:
The main difference between the COPY and ADD commands in a Dockerfile is that ADD also supports fetching files from a URL and automatically decompressing tar archives. COPY only supports copying local files from the build context (the files and directories in the current directory when the Docker build command is run).

So, if you want to copy a file from the local build context, you should use COPY. If you want to fetch a file from a URL or automatically decompress a tar archive, you should use ADD.

Note that both COPY and ADD can cause increased image size and slow down the build process, so it's best to keep them to a minimum in your Dockerfiles.

INPUT:question:
How does JavaScript .prototype work?
I'm not that into dynamic programming languages but I've written my fair share of JavaScript code. I never really got my head around this prototype-based programming, does any one know how this works?
var obj = new Object();
obj.prototype.test = function() { alert('Hello?'); };
var obj2 = new obj();
obj2.test();
I remember a lot discussion I had with people a while back (I'm not exactly sure what I'm doing) but as I understand it, there's no concept of a class. It's just an object, and instances of those objects are clones of the original, right?
But what is the exact purpose of this ".prototype" property in JavaScript? How does it relate to instantiating objects?
Update: correct way
var obj = new Object(); // not a functional object
obj.prototype.test = function() { alert('Hello?'); }; // this is wrong!
function MyObject() {} // a first class functional object
MyObject.prototype.test = function() { alert('OK'); } // OK
Also these slides really helped a lot.
OUTPUT:answer:
JavaScript uses prototype-based programming, which is different from class-based programming in languages like Java or C#. In JavaScript, there is no concept of classes, only objects. When you create an object, it has an internal property called prototype, which is a reference to another object.

The prototype property is used to share properties and methods between objects. If you try to access a property or a method on an object and it can't be found, JavaScript will look for it on the object's prototype. This is called prototype chaining, and it is how inheritance is implemented in JavaScript.

In the code example you provided, obj is an instance of the built-in Object object. However, you cannot add properties to obj.prototype directly because obj is not a function object. Functions are used to create objects in JavaScript, and they have their own prototype property.

The correct way to add properties to the prototype of a custom object type is to create a function object and add properties to its prototype property. In the updated code example, you created a function MyObject and added a test method to its prototype property. This way, when you create an instance of MyObject using var obj2 = new MyObject(), it will have access to the test method via prototype chaining.

INPUT:question:
403 Forbidden vs 401 Unauthorized HTTP responses
For a web page that exists, but for which a user does not have sufficient privileges (they are not logged in or do not belong to the proper user group), what is the proper HTTP response to serve?
401 Unauthorized?
403 Forbidden?
Something else?
What I've read on each so far isn't very clear on the difference between the two. What use cases are appropriate for each response?
OUTPUT:answer:
The proper HTTP response to serve in case a user doesn't have sufficient privileges to access a web page is 401 Unauthorized. The 401 response is intended to indicate that the user needs to authenticate in order to access the requested resource.

On the other hand, 403 Forbidden is used to indicate that the server understands the request, but it refuses to authorize it. This status is similar to 401 (Unauthorized), but indicates that authentication will not help. A 403 response is not a guarantee that the client will not be able to access the requested resource; it simply means that the server will not provide the requested information.

In summary:

401 Unauthorized is used to indicate that authentication is required and has failed or has not been provided.
403 Forbidden is used to indicate that the server refuses to authorize the request, regardless of whether authentication is provided or not.

INPUT:question:
NPM vs. Bower vs. Browserify vs. Gulp vs. Grunt vs. Webpack
I'm trying to summarize my knowledge about the most popular JavaScript package managers, bundlers, and task runners. Please correct me if I'm wrong:
npm & bower are package managers. They just download the dependencies and don't know how to build projects on their own. What they know is to call webpack/gulp/grunt after fetching all the dependencies.
bower is like npm, but builds a flattened dependency trees (unlike npm which does it recursively). Meaning npm fetches the dependencies for each dependency (may fetch the same a few times), while bower expects you to manually include sub-dependencies. Sometimes bower and npm are used together for front-end and back-end respectively (since each megabyte might matter in front-end).
grunt and gulp are task runners to automate everything that can be automated (i.e. compile CSS/Sass, optimize images, make a bundle and minify/transpile it).
grunt vs. gulp (is like maven vs. gradle or configuration vs. code). Grunt is based on configuring separate independent tasks, each task opens/handles/closes file. Gulp requires less amount of code and is based on Node streams, which allows it to build pipe chains (w/o reopening the same file) and makes it faster. 
webpack (webpack-dev-server) - for me it's a task runner with hot reloading of changes which allows you to forget about all JS/CSS watchers. 
npm/bower + plugins may replace task runners. Their abilities often intersect so there are different implications if you need to use gulp/grunt over npm + plugins. But task runners are definitely better for complex tasks (e.g. "on each build create bundle, transpile from ES6 to ES5, run it at all browsers emulators, make screenshots and deploy to dropbox through ftp").
browserify allows packaging node modules for browsers. browserify vs node's require is actually AMD vs CommonJS.
Questions:
What is webpack & webpack-dev-server? Official documentation says it's a module bundler but for me it's just a task runner. What's the difference?
Where would you use browserify? Can't we do the same with node/ES6 imports? 
When would you use gulp/grunt over npm + plugins?
Please provide examples when you need to use a combination
OUTPUT:answer:
You have a good overall understanding of these tools. Here are a few corrections and additional points:

npm and bower are both package managers, but bower was originally created to manage front-end dependencies (e.g. libraries and frameworks) while npm was created for managing back-end dependencies. Nowadays, npm has become the de facto package manager for both front-end and back-end JavaScript packages.
Grunt and gulp are both task runners, but gulp uses a more code-based approach, using JavaScript functions and pipelines to automate tasks, while Grunt uses a configuration file to define tasks.
Webpack is not just a task runner, it's a module bundler. It takes your code and dependencies, and generates static assets (bundles) that can be included in a web page. It also has built-in optimization features like minification, code splitting, and tree shaking. The webpack-dev-server is a development server that uses webpack under the hood, and provides features like hot reloading and automatic bundling on changes.
You would use browserify if you want to use node modules in the browser, for example if you want to use a node module that wasn't designed for use in the browser. It allows you to package your node modules and their dependencies into a single bundle that can be included in a web page, and provides a compatible require function for those modules to use.
You would use gulp or Grunt over npm + plugins when you have complex tasks that require multiple steps and/or multiple plugins. The plugins available through npm can be used with task runners to automate these complex tasks. For example, you could use gulp to compile your Sass into CSS, minify your CSS and JavaScript, and then use webpack to bundle your code.
There is no one-size-fits-all answer for when you need to use a combination of these tools. It depends on the specific requirements of your project and your personal preferences. However, a common combination is to use npm for managing packages, gulp or Grunt for automating tasks, and webpack for bundling your code for the browser.

OUTPUT:answer:
To find out which process is listening on a TCP or UDP port on Windows, you can use the "netstat" command.

Here is the basic syntax for using "netstat" to display a list of active TCP connections and the process ID (PID) for each connection:

css
Copy code
netstat -a -n -o
You can use the following command to find the process listening on a specific port, for example port 80:

lua
Copy code
netstat -a -n -o | find ":80"
You can also use the "Task Manager" to find the process listening on a port. Right-click the taskbar and select "Task Manager," then go to the "Details" tab and look for the process name with the corresponding PID. You can then match the PID with the PID displayed in the "netstat" output.

OUTPUT:answer:
The .PHONY target in a Makefile is used to specify that a target is not a real file and its dependencies should always be built, even if a file with the same name exists in the file system. It is a way to specify which targets are considered "phony" (fake) and should always run their commands, rather than just updating the target if it's considered "out of date".

For example, if you have a clean target in your Makefile, you might want to specify it as .PHONY so that make clean always runs the specified commands to clean up your project, regardless of whether a file named clean exists in your file system or not.

In simple terms, .PHONY makes sure that a target always runs its specified commands, rather than just updating the target if its dependencies change.

When should static_cast, dynamic_cast, const_cast, and reinterpret_cast be used?
What are the proper uses of:
static_cast
dynamic_cast
const_cast
reinterpret_cast
(type)value (C-style cast)
type(value) (function-style cast)
How does one decide which to use in which specific cases?
OUTPUT:answer:
static_cast is used for type casting between compatible data types. It can perform conversions such as int to float, derived class to base class, and void pointer to any other pointer type. static_cast performs only basic type checking and is used for low-level conversions that the programmer fully understands and trusts.

dynamic_cast is used for type casting between related classes in an inheritance hierarchy. It performs a runtime check to ensure that the type being cast to is indeed the correct type. If the cast fails, a nullptr is returned. dynamic_cast is typically used when working with polymorphic objects and is a safer alternative to static_cast in such cases.

const_cast is used to remove or add the const qualifier from a variable. This can be useful when passing a const argument to a function that does not accept a const argument.

reinterpret_cast is used for low-level bit manipulation and conversions that do not preserve the underlying value. reinterpret_cast can be used to convert a pointer of one type to a pointer of another type, even if the types are not related. This can result in undefined behavior and should be used with caution.

The C-style cast (type)value is a shorthand for static_cast, but also includes reinterpret_cast and const_cast. It is often used for quick and dirty type casting, but is considered less safe than the other casting methods as it can cause unexpected behavior and make code harder to understand and maintain.

The function-style cast type(value) is a shorthand for static_cast.

When deciding which cast to use, it's important to consider the safety of the operation, the compatibility of the data types, and the purpose of the cast. If the purpose is to convert between compatible data types, use static_cast. If the purpose is to perform a type check on an object in an inheritance hierarchy, use dynamic_cast. If the purpose is to modify the const qualifier, use const_cast. And if the purpose is to perform low-level bit manipulation, use reinterpret_cast only if necessary and with caution.

INPUT:question:
Ignore files that have already been committed to a Git repository
I have an already initialized Git repository that I added a .gitignore file to. How can I refresh the file index so the files I want ignored get ignored?
OUTPUT:answer:
You can refresh the file index by executing the following steps:

    Add the updated .gitignore file to the repository with git add .gitignore
    Commit the changes with git commit -m "Updated .gitignore"
    Remove the untracked files from the Git repository with git rm -r --cached .
    Commit the changes again with git commit -m "Removed ignored files"

This will remove the files you want ignored from the Git repository, and they will remain ignored in future commits.

SELECT email, COUNT(email) 
FROM users
GROUP BY email
HAVING COUNT(email) > 1
So if we have a table
ID   NAME   EMAIL

3    Tom    asd@asd.com
4    Bob    bob@asd.com
5    Tom    asd@asd.com

OUTPUT:answer:
You can find duplicates with multiple fields by adding those fields to the SELECT and GROUP BY statements:

SELECT name, email, COUNT()
FROM users
GROUP BY name, email
HAVING COUNT() > 1;

INPUT:question:
What is a smart pointer and when should I use one?
What is a smart pointer and when should I use one?
OUTPUT:answer:
A smart pointer is a type of object in C++ that acts like a pointer, but with additional features and automatic memory management. They are designed to help prevent common memory management problems, such as memory leaks and use-after-free bugs, by automatically freeing dynamically allocated memory when it is no longer needed.

There are several types of smart pointers in C++, including std::unique_ptr, std::shared_ptr, and std::weak_ptr.

You should use smart pointers whenever you need to dynamically allocate memory in your C++ program. By using smart pointers, you can ensure that memory is automatically freed when it is no longer needed, even if an exception is thrown, which helps to prevent memory leaks and other related issues. Additionally, smart pointers provide a safer, more convenient way to manage dynamically allocated memory than traditional raw pointers.

Smart pointers are especially useful when working with complex data structures, such as trees and graphs, where the lifetime of dynamically allocated objects is difficult to manage manually. By using smart pointers, you can simplify the management of dynamically allocated memory and reduce the risk of memory-related bugs in your code.

INPUT:question:
Throw away local commits in Git
Due to some bad cherry-picking, my local Git repository is currently five commits ahead of the origin, and not in a good state. I want to get rid of all these commits and start over again.
Obviously, deleting my working directory and re-cloning would do it, but downloading everything from GitHub again seems like overkill, and not a good use of my time.
Maybe git revert is what I need, but I don't want to end up 10 commits ahead of the origin (or even six), even if it does get the code itself back to the right state. I just want to pretend the last half-hour never happened.
Is there a simple command that will do this? It seems like an obvious use case, but I'm not finding any examples of it.
Note that this question is specifically about commits, not about:
untracked files
unstaged changes
staged, but uncommitted changes
OUTPUT:answer:
You can use git reset to throw away local commits. The following command will reset your branch to the latest commit on the origin branch:

bash

git reset --hard origin/branch_name

This will effectively erase all local commits and bring your branch in line with the remote branch. Make sure to replace branch_name with the actual name of your branch.

Alternatively, you can use git fetch followed by git reset to achieve the same result:

sql

git fetch origin
git reset --hard origin/branch_name

"Regular cast" (also known as "C-style cast") is a type of cast that allows you to convert one data type to another in C++. It is flexible but can lead to unexpected results if used improperly.

"Static cast" is a type of cast that performs compile-time type checking. It can convert any compatible data type to any other compatible data type. If the cast fails, the program will not compile.

"Dynamic cast" is a type of cast that performs run-time type checking. It can only be used to cast a pointer or reference to a derived class to a pointer or reference to a base class. If the cast fails, a null pointer or exception is returned.

In summary:

Use regular cast if you need to perform a conversion that is not possible with other casts.
Use static cast if you are sure the conversion is safe and want to avoid run-time checks.
Use dynamic cast if you need to perform a downcast (i.e., cast from base class to derived class) and need to check at runtime if the cast is valid.

INPUT:question:
What's the difference between a method and a function?
Can someone provide a simple explanation of methods vs. functions in OOP context?
OUTPUT:answer:
In object-oriented programming (OOP), a method is a function that is associated with an object, while a function is a standalone piece of code that can be called anywhere in a program.

A method is defined within a

network error
class and is used to manipulate or access the properties of an object created from the class. A method can access and modify the data members of an object and also call other methods within the same class.

On the other hand, a function is a standalone code block that can be called from anywhere in a program. A function is not associated with any object and operates independently of any object. Functions can be defined outside of a class and can be called without creating an object.

In summary, a method is a function that is associated with an object, and is used to manipulate or access the properties of that object, while a function is a standalone piece of code that can be called from anywhere in a program, and operates independently of any object.

Why doesn't GCC optimize a*a*a*a*a*a to (a*a*a)*(a*a*a)?
I am doing some numerical optimization on a scientific application. (In contrast, Intel C++ Compiler, executable icc, will eliminate the library call for pow(a,6).) 
What I am curious about is that when I replaced pow(a,6) with a*a*a*a*a*a using GCC 4.5.1 and options "-O3 -lm -funroll-loops -msse4", it uses 5 mulsd instructions:
movapd  %xmm14, %xmm13
mulsd   %xmm14, %xmm13
mulsd   %xmm14, %xmm13
mulsd   %xmm14, %xmm13
mulsd   %xmm14, %xmm13
mulsd   %xmm14, %xmm13
while if I write (a*a*a)*(a*a*a), it will produce
movapd  %xmm14, %xmm13
mulsd   %xmm14, %xmm13
mulsd   %xmm14, %xmm13
mulsd   %xmm13, %xmm13
which reduces the number of multiply instructions to 3. icc has similar behavior.
Why do compilers not recognize this optimization trick?
OUTPUT:answer:
Compilers use a set of optimization techniques to make code run faster and use fewer resources. However, the set of optimizations that a compiler uses is limited, and some optimizations may not be possible or may have unintended side effects. In the case of the expression aaaaaa, it is not trivial for the compiler to recognize that it can be optimized to (aaa)(aaa). This optimization requires the compiler to be able to recognize that the expression can be simplified, to understand the associative property of multiplication, and to reorder the operations in a way that results in fewer instructions. While this optimization is possible, it may not be high on the list of priorities for the compiler developers.
In general, compilers are designed to handle a large set of inputs, and may not be optimized for specific cases like this one. If performance is a concern, it may be helpful to manually optimize the code, or to consider using a different compiler.

INPUT:question:
What is the "N+1 selects problem" in ORM (Object-Relational Mapping)?
The "N+1 selects problem" is generally stated as a problem in Object-Relational mapping (ORM) discussions, and I understand that it has something to do with having to make a lot of database queries for something that seems simple in the object world.
Does anybody have a more detailed explanation of the problem?
OUTPUT:answer:
The "N+1 selects problem" refers to the performance issue that arises when using ORMs to interact with a relational database. It occurs when a single parent object is retrieved from the database, followed by multiple child objects, resulting in "N+1" database queries.

Here's an example to illustrate the problem: consider a scenario where you have a "User" object that has many "Orders". To display all the orders of a user, you might write code that first retrieves the user object, and then retrieves all of their orders. With an ORM, the code would look something like this:

makefile

# First query to retrieve the user object
user = User.find(user_id)

# One additional query per order to retrieve the orders
orders = [Order.find(order_id) for order_id in user.order_ids]

In this example, you would end up with N+1 database queries, where N is the number of orders for the user. This is inefficient because it creates an excessive number of round trips to the database for data that is related, leading to poor performance, particularly when N is large.

To avoid the N+1 selects problem, you can use techniques such as eager loading or batch loading to load related data in a single query, reducing the number of round trips to the database.

INPUT:question:
How to check if a string contains a substring in Bash
I have a string in Bash:
string="My string"
How can I test if it contains another string?
if [ $string ?? 'foo' ]; then
  echo "It's there!"
fi
Where ?? is my unknown operator. Do I use echo and grep?
if echo "$string" | grep 'foo'; then
  echo "It's there!"
fi
That looks a bit clumsy.
OUTPUT:answer:
You can use the "*" wildcard and square brackets "[]" in the following way to check if a string contains a substring in Bash:

bash

if [[ "$string" == *"foo"* ]]; then
  echo "It's there!"
fi

Or you can use the "case" statement:

bash

case "$string" in
  *foo*)
    echo "It's there!"
    ;;
esac

INPUT:question:
Extract filename and extension in Bash

This is wrong because it doesn't work if the file name contains multiple . characters. If, let's say, I have a.b.js, it will consider a and b.js, instead of a.b and js.
It can be easily done in Python with
file, ext = os.path.splitext(path)
but I'd prefer not to fire up a Python interpreter just for this, if possible.
Any better ideas?
OUTPUT:answer:
You can use parameter expansion in bash to extract the filename and extension:

makefile

filename="a.b.js"
extension="${filename##*.}"
name="${filename%.*}"

This method uses the parameter expansion feature in bash to remove the shortest match from the front (##) or the back (%) of the filename variable to extract the extension or name, respectively.

INPUT:question:
What is Inversion of Control?
Inversion of Control (IoC) can be quite confusing when it is first encountered.
What is it?
Which problem does it solve?
When is it appropriate to use and when not?
OUTPUT:answer:
Inversion of Control (IoC) is a design principle in which the flow of control of a system is reversed, meaning that instead of the client code controlling the flow, it is the framework or the container that controls the flow of execution.

IoC solves the problem of tight coupling between the client code and the implementation, which can make the system rigid, hard to maintain, and difficult to test. By using IoC, the client code can be decoupled from the implementation and can be easily swapped with another implementation without affecting the client code.

IoC is appropriate to use when building applications that are complex, with multiple dependencies, or when creating reusable components. It is not appropriate to use when the application is simple and has limited dependencies, as it can add unnecessary complexity and overhead to the system.

Both event.preventDefault() and return false serve the same purpose in stopping event propagation, but there is a difference between them. event.preventDefault() only prevents the default behavior of the event, while return false also stops the propagation of the event to its parent elements. So, if you only need to prevent the default behavior, use event.preventDefault(), but if you also need to stop the propagation, use return false. In terms of which is better, it depends on your specific use case, but using event.preventDefault() is generally considered best practice as it provides more fine-grained control over the events.

css

Replace "username" with your MySQL username and enter your password when prompted.

Create a database if it does not already exist:

sql

Use the database you just created:

Import the .sql file using the following command:
bash
Copy code

Replace "C:/file.sql" with the full path to your .sql file.

If the import was successful, you should see a message indicating that the query has been executed.

INPUT:question:
What is the difference between an interface and abstract class?
What exactly is the difference between an interface and an abstract class?
OUTPUT:answer:
An interface defines a contract that specifies a set of methods that a class must implement, but doesn't provide any implementation for those methods. An abstract class is a base class that can contain both abstract methods (without implementation) and concrete methods (with implementation). A class that extends an abstract class must provide implementation for all abstract methods, but can also add its own methods and fields.

In short, an interface is used to define a blueprint for classes and can only contain abstract methods, while an abstract class can provide some implementation along with the blueprint for its subclasses.

INPUT:question:
What is a non-capturing group in regular expressions?
How are non-capturing groups, i.e., (?:), used in regular expressions and what are they good for?
OUTPUT:answer:
A non-capturing group in regular expressions is a group that is created using the syntax (?:...) instead of the usual syntax (...). Unlike a capturing group, a non-capturing group does not capture the text matched by the group and store it as a separate group that can be retrieved later.

Non-capturing groups are used to group regular expressions together for the purpose of applying operators (such as | or ?) to the entire group, without capturing the text matched by the group. They are particularly useful when you need to group a pattern but do not need to capture the text matched by the group.

For example, consider the following pattern: (a(?:b|c)). The group (a(?:b|c)) is a non-capturing group, and the group (b|c) is a capturing group. The pattern matches the string "ab" or "ac", but only the text matched by the capturing group is stored, which is either "b" or "c".

INPUT:question:
How to make a great R reproducible example
When discussing performance with colleagues, teaching, sending a bug report or searching for guidance on mailing lists and here on Stack Overflow, a reproducible example is often asked and always helpful.
What are your tips for creating an excellent example? How do you paste data structures from r in a text format? What other information should you include?
Are there other tricks in addition to using dput(), dump() or structure()?  When should you include library() or require() statements?  Which reserved words should one avoid, in addition to c, df, data, etc.?
How does one make a great r reproducible example?
OUTPUT:answer:
Here are some tips to make a great R reproducible example:

    Keep it minimal: Only include the minimum amount of code necessary to demonstrate the issue.

    Include sample data: Use dput() or dump() to paste data structures in a text format. If the data is too large, consider using a subset of the data or creating a synthetic example.

    Specify the R version and package versions: Include the output of sessionInfo() to provide information about the R version and the versions of the packages being used.

    Use meaningful variable names: Avoid using reserved words such as "c" or "df" and choose descriptive names for variables instead.

    Include library() or require() statements: Specify the packages required to run the code.

    Use clear and concise comments: Provide a brief description of the issue and any other relevant information.

    Test the code: Make sure the example is self-contained and can be run without errors.

    Use a code formatting tool: Properly indent and format the code to make it easier to read.

By following these tips, you can create a great R reproducible example that will help others understand your issue and provide a solution more effectively.

INPUT:question:
How do I parse command line arguments in Bash?
Say, I have a script that gets called with this line:
./myscript -vfd ./foo/bar/someFile -o /fizz/someOtherFile
or this one:
./myscript -v -f -d -o /fizz/someOtherFile ./foo/bar/someFile 
What's the accepted way of parsing this such that in each case (or some combination of the two) $v, $f, and  $d will all be set to true and $outFile will be equal to /fizz/someOtherFile?
OUTPUT:answer:
You can parse command line arguments in Bash using the getopts or getopt commands. Here's an example using getopts:

bash

#!/bin/bash

v=false
f=false
d=false

while getopts "vfdo:" opt; do
  case $opt in
    v)
      v=true
      ;;
    f)
      f=true
      ;;
    d)
      d=true
      ;;
    o)
      outFile="$OPTARG"
      ;;
    \?)
      echo "Invalid option: -$OPTARG" >&2
      exit 1
      ;;
  esac
done

shift $((OPTIND-1))
inFile="$1"

echo "v: $v"
echo "f: $f"
echo "d: $d"
echo "inFile: $inFile"
echo "outFile: $outFile"

This will produce the following output:

bash

$ ./myscript -vfd ./foo/bar/someFile -o /fizz/someOtherFile
v: true
f: true
d: true
inFile: ./foo/bar/someFile
outFile: /fizz/someOtherFile

$ ./myscript -v -f -d -o /fizz/someOtherFile ./foo/bar/someFile
v: true
f: true
d: true
inFile: ./foo/bar/someFile
outFile: /fizz/someOtherFile

INPUT:question:
AngularJS: Service vs provider vs factory
What are the differences between a Service, Provider and Factory in AngularJS?
OUTPUT:answer:
In AngularJS, Service, Provider, and Factory are all different ways to create reusable objects that can be shared across multiple components in an application.

    Service: A Service is a simple function that is created using the .service method. It is the simplest way to create a reusable object, and it is mainly used for data and logic that needs to be shared between multiple controllers.

    Factory: A Factory is a more flexible way to create reusable objects, as it can return any value, including objects, functions, and primitive values. It is created using the .factory method, and it is a more commonly used option as it provides more control over the object that is returned.

    Provider: A Provider is the most powerful and flexible way to create reusable objects in AngularJS, as it allows you to configure the object before it is created and returned to the consumer. It is created using the .provider method, and it is mainly used for objects that require configuration, such as a service that needs to be configured with an API endpoint.

In conclusion, while Service and Factory provide simple and flexible ways to create reusable objects, Provider offers the most control over the configuration and creation of these objects.

OUTPUT:answer:
The ??!??! operator does not exist in the C programming language, and it is not part of any standard. It appears to be an error or a custom operator created by the programmer. The line of code in question might not function as expected and could result in unintended behavior.

It's always a good idea to use well-documented and established programming constructs, rather than relying on custom or undefined behavior, for the sake of code maintainability and portability.

INPUT:question:
What do two question marks together mean in C#?
Ran across this line of code:
FormsAuth = formsAuth ?? new FormsAuthenticationWrapper();
What do the two question marks mean, is it some kind of ternary operator?
It's hard to look up in Google.
OUTPUT:answer:
Yes, the two question marks in this line of code are known as the null-coalescing operator in C#. The operator provides a shorthand way to handle cases where a value may be null. The syntax of the operator is as follows:

css

a = b ?? c

The expression a = b ?? c means: If b is not null, then a is assigned the value of b, otherwise a is assigned the value of c.

In your example, formsAuth ?? new FormsAuthenticationWrapper() means: If formsAuth is not null, then FormsAuth is assigned the value of formsAuth, otherwise FormsAuth is assigned the value of new FormsAuthenticationWrapper().

INPUT:question:
What's the difference between dependencies, devDependencies and peerDependencies in npm package.json file?
This documentation answers my question very poorly. I didn't understand those explanations. Can someone say in simpler words? Maybe with examples if it's hard to choose simple words?
EDIT also added peerDependencies, which is closely related and might cause confusion.
OUTPUT:answer:
"dependencies" are packages required for your application to run.

"devDependencies" are packages required for development and building of the application. Examples include testing frameworks, build tools, etc.

"peerDependencies" are packages required by the libraries/plugins your application is using. It means if your application is using a library that requires a certain version of a package, you have to install that specific version.

Here's an example to help clarify:

Imagine you're building a web application and you're using the library "React". In your package.json file, you would list "React" as a "dependency".

Now imagine you're using a testing framework called "Jest" for testing your application. In your package.json file, you would list "Jest" as a "devDependency".

And finally, imagine that the library you're using, "React", has a peer dependency on "React DOM". That means the library you're using requires you to install "React DOM". You would list "React DOM" as a "peerDependency" in your package.json file.

INPUT:question:
How do I remedy "The breakpoint will not currently be hit. No symbols have been loaded for this document." warning?
A C# desktop application (on the Visual Studio Express edition) worked, but then it didn't work 5 seconds later.
I tried the following:
Ensure debug configuration, debug flag, and full debug information are set on all assemblies.
Delete all bin and obj folders and all DLL files related to the project from my entire machine.
Recreate projects causing the problem from scratch.
Reboot.
I have two Windows Forms projects in the solution. One of them loads the debug information, one doesn't. They both refer to the assembly I'm trying to get debug information on in exactly the same way in the project file. Any ideas?
I want to add here, mostly for myself when I come back to review this question, that symbols are not loaded until the assembly is loaded, and the assembly is not loaded until it is needed. If the breakpoint is in a library that is only used in one function in your main assembly, the symbols will not be loaded (and it will show the breakpoint as not being hit) until that function is called.
OUTPUT:answer:
The "The breakpoint will not currently be hit. No symbols have been loaded for this document" warning can occur when the symbols for the code you are trying to debug are not loaded. To resolve this issue, try the following:

    Check if the symbols for the code are loaded.
    Check if the symbol files (.pdb) are in the same location as the binary files (.dll or .exe).
    If the symbols are not loaded, make sure that the "Enable Just My Code" option is disabled in Visual Studio under "Tools > Options > Debugging".
    Make sure that the "Enable source server support" option is enabled in Visual Studio under "Tools > Options > Debugging".
    Check if the symbol servers are correctly configured in Visual Studio under "Tools > Options > Debugging > Symbols".
    Check if the code is built with the "Debug" configuration.
    If the issue still persists, try cleaning and rebuilding the solution and restarting Visual Studio.

If all of these steps fail, try repairing or reinstalling Visual Studio.

OUTPUT:answer:
Yes, you can use the docker save and docker load commands to transfer Docker images between hosts.

    On the machine where the image is located, save it as a tar archive:

docker save myimage > myimage.tar

    Copy the tar archive to the target machine, for example using scp:

ruby

scp myimage.tar user@target:/path/to/myimage.tar

    Load the image on the target machine:

lua

docker load < myimage.tar

This will import the image into the Docker daemon on the target machine, making it available for use.

INPUT:question:
What's the difference between INNER JOIN, LEFT JOIN, RIGHT JOIN and FULL JOIN?
What's the difference between INNER JOIN, LEFT JOIN, RIGHT JOIN and FULL JOIN 
in MySQL?
OUTPUT:answer:
INNER JOIN, LEFT JOIN, RIGHT JOIN, and FULL JOIN are all types of SQL joins used to combine data from two or more tables based on a related column between them.

INNER JOIN returns only the rows from both tables where the join condition is met.

LEFT JOIN returns all the rows from the left table (the first table in the LEFT JOIN clause), and the matching rows from the right table (the second table in the LEFT JOIN clause), and NULL values for non-matching rows from the right table.

RIGHT JOIN returns all the rows from the right table (the second table in the RIGHT JOIN clause), and the matching rows from the left table (the first table in the RIGHT JOIN clause), and NULL values for non-matching rows from the left table.

FULL JOIN returns all rows from both tables, and NULL values for non-matching rows from either the left or right table.

INPUT:question:
What are the differences between .gitignore and .gitkeep?
What are the differences between .gitignore and .gitkeep? Are they the same thing with a different name, or do they both serve a different function?
I don't seem to be able to find much documentation on .gitkeep.
OUTPUT:answer:
.gitignore and .gitkeep are different files that serve different purposes.

.gitignore is used to specify files and directories that Git should ignore and not track. When a file or directory is listed in .gitignore, Git will not stage changes made to those files and will not track them in the repository.

.gitkeep, on the other hand, is a placeholder file that is used to keep an empty directory in a Git repository. An empty directory in Git is ignored and will not be tracked unless a .gitkeep file is added to it.

In other words, .gitignore is used to ignore files and directories that should not be tracked, while .gitkeep is used to keep empty directories that should be tracked.

You can make a placeholder for a select box by setting the default selected value to be a disabled option with your desired placeholder text. For example:

vbnet

<select>
  <option value="" disabled selected>Select your option</option>
  <option value="hurr">Durr</option>
</select>

Then, you can use CSS to style the default selected option with a light gray color:

css

select option[disabled] {
  color: #999;
}

This will make the default selected option have a light gray color, and after a real option is selected, its color will be the default (usually black).

In Python, the * (single star) and ** (double star) operators are used to pass a variable number of arguments to a function.

The * operator is used to pass a non-keyworded, variable-length argument list to a function. The syntax is:

python
Copy code
def foo(x, y, *args):
Here, args is a tuple that contains all the additional non-keyworded arguments passed to the function.

The ** operator is used to pass keyworded, variable-length argument dictionaries to a function. The syntax is:

python
Copy code
def bar(x, y, **kwargs):
Here, kwargs is a dictionary that contains all the additional keyworded arguments passed to the function.

The terms *args and **kwargs are conventional names for the variable-length argument lists and dictionaries, respectively, but you can use any other name in their place.

INPUT:question:
How do I change the author and committer name/email for multiple commits?
How do I change the author for a range of commits?
OUTPUT:answer:
You can change the author and committer information for multiple commits in Git by using the "git filter-branch" command. Here's an example:

makefile

# Change the author information for all commits in the current branch
git filter-branch --env-filter '

OLD_EMAIL="old-email@example.com"
CORRECT_NAME="Correct Name"
CORRECT_EMAIL="correct-email@example.com"

if [ "$GIT_COMMITTER_EMAIL" = "$OLD_EMAIL" ]
then
    export GIT_COMMITTER_NAME="$CORRECT_NAME"
    export GIT_COMMITTER_EMAIL="$CORRECT_EMAIL"
fi
if [ "$GIT_AUTHOR_EMAIL" = "$OLD_EMAIL" ]
then
    export GIT_AUTHOR_NAME="$CORRECT_NAME"
    export GIT_AUTHOR_EMAIL="$CORRECT_EMAIL"
fi
' --tag-name-filter cat -- --branches --tags

# Push the updated history to the remote repository
git push --force --tags origin 'refs/heads/*'

In this example, replace OLD_EMAIL with the incorrect email address, and replace CORRECT_NAME and CORRECT_EMAIL with the desired author name and email. The --force flag is necessary when pushing the updated history to the remote repository. Be careful when using this command, as it will rewrite the entire branch history, which can cause problems if you've already shared the branch with others.

INPUT:question:
Is floating point math broken?
Consider the following code:
0.1 + 0.2 == 0.3  ->  false
0.1 + 0.2         ->  0.30000000000000004
Why do these inaccuracies happen?
OUTPUT:answer: The inaccuracies in floating-point math occur because it is a finite, binary representation of real numbers, while most real numbers can't be exactly represented in a finite binary form. So, the actual value stored in the computer's memory is close to but not exactly 0.1 or 0.2, and this approximation leads to the inaccuracies when performing operations like addition. This is why 0.1 + 0.2 is not exactly equal to 0.3 but instead yields 0.30000000000000004.

There are several ways to improve the INSERT performance of SQLite:

Use transactions: wrap multiple INSERT statements into a single transaction, this can greatly improve the bulk insert performance.
Use prepared statements: compile SQL statements once and execute them multiple times, this can save the overhead of parsing SQL statements multiple times.
Use batch processing: group multiple INSERT statements into a single string and execute it as a single SQL statement, this can reduce the overhead of making multiple trips to the database.
Use the sqlite3_exec function: this function is designed for executing multiple SQL statements at once, which can reduce the overhead of making multiple trips to the database.
Increase the cache size: the cache size affects the performance of SQLite, increasing the cache size can improve the INSERT performance.
Use the WAL (Write-Ahead Logging) mode: WAL mode can improve the write performance of SQLite, it's recommended to use it if you need high INSERT performance.
Consider using other databases: If the performance of SQLite is still not sufficient, consider using other databases, such as MySQL or PostgreSQL, which may provide better performance for your use case.

Casting the result of malloc is not necessary in modern C programming and can be considered as a potential source of errors. The C standard guarantees that the return value of malloc is of type void *, which can be automatically converted to any other pointer type, including int *, without the need for an explicit cast.

Additionally, casting the result of malloc can hide type mismatches that can lead to bugs, and can also make the code less readable and harder to maintain.

Therefore, it's recommended to avoid casting the result of malloc and to use the type-safe form of malloc, as shown in the first example.

INPUT:question:

listone = [1, 2, 3]
listtwo = [4, 5, 6]
Expected outcome:

[1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]
OUTPUT:answer:
You can concatenate two lists in Python using the "+" operator or the extend method.

makefile
Copy code
listone = [1, 2, 3]
listtwo = [4, 5, 6]

# Using the + operator:
joinedlist = listone + listtwo
print(joinedlist)
# Output: [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]

An interface and a type in TypeScript are both ways to describe the shape of an object, but they are used in different ways and have different features.

An interface in TypeScript is a contract that defines the structure of an object, including the properties and methods it should have. Interfaces are usually used to describe the structure of complex objects, and can be used for object typing, inheritance, and polymorphism.

A type in TypeScript is a way to give a name to any value, including primitive values, objects, functions, and arrays. A type alias is a type definition that can be used to describe an object, similar to an interface.

In this specific case, both the interface and type alias have the same structure and purpose, but an interface provides more functionality and is the recommended way to describe the structure of an object in TypeScript.

INPUT:question:
Why is "using namespace std;" considered bad practice?
I have heard using namespace std; is bad practice, and that I should use std::cout and std::cin directly instead.
Why is this? Does it risk declaring variables that share the same name as something in the std namespace?
OUTPUT:answer:
Yes, using "using namespace std;" is considered bad practice because it can lead to name collisions and make it harder to understand where certain functions or variables are coming from. The standard library (std) contains many common names, such as "cout" and "cin". If you bring the entire namespace into scope with "using namespace std;", and if you or another part of your code defines a variable or function with the same name as something in the std namespace, it could lead to unexpected behavior or bugs that are difficult to debug.

By explicitly specifying "std::" before each item from the standard library, you make it clear where each symbol is coming from and reduce the risk of naming conflicts. This also makes the code easier to maintain and understand for yourself and others.

INPUT:question:
Detach (move) subdirectory into separate Git repository
I have a Git repository which contains a number of subdirectories. Now I have found that one of the subdirectories is unrelated to the other and should be detached to a separate repository.
How can I do this while keeping the history of the files within the subdirectory?
I guess I could make a clone and remove the unwanted parts of each clone, but I suppose this would give me the complete tree when checking out an older revision etc. This might be acceptable, but I would prefer to be able to pretend that the two repositories doesn't have a shared history.
Just to make it clear, I have the following structure:
XYZ/
    .git/
    XY1/
    ABC/
    XY2/
But I would like this instead:
XYZ/
    .git/
    XY1/
    XY2/
ABC/
    .git/
    ABC/
OUTPUT:answer:
You can use git filter-branch to extract the history of the subdirectory "ABC" into a separate repository. Here's how:

Create a new directory for the separate repository:

shell
Copy code
$ mkdir ABC
$ cd ABC
Initialize a new Git repository:

csharp
Copy code
$ git init
Add a remote to the original repository:

csharp
Copy code
$ git remote add -f original ../XYZ
Use git filter-branch to extract only the relevant history:

css
Copy code
$ git filter-branch --prune-empty --subdirectory-filter ABC original/master
Push the extracted history to a new remote repository:

csharp
Copy code
$ git remote add origin <url-of-new-repository>
$ git push -u origin master
Now, you have a separate Git repository with the history of the "ABC" subdirectory. The original repository still contains the other subdirectories.

INPUT:question:
What's the difference between SCSS and Sass?
From what I've been reading, Sass is a language that makes CSS more powerful with variable and math support. 
What's the difference with SCSS? Is it supposed to be the same language? Similar? Different?
OUTPUT:answer: SCSS (Sassy CSS) is a syntax extension of CSS and it is completely compatible with CSS. It is a CSS preprocessor, meaning that it extends the CSS language, adding features that allow variables, mixins, functions, and mathematical operations. Sass is an older syntax for the same CSS preprocessor. The syntax for Sass is less CSS-like and more like a scripting language, whereas SCSS has a syntax that is more closely modeled after CSS and is often considered easier to learn for those already familiar with CSS. In short, SCSS is an extension of Sass that provides a CSS-like syntax and is fully compatible with CSS, making it an easier transition for people already familiar with CSS.

INPUT:question:
What are MVP and MVC and what is the difference?
When looking beyond the RAD (drag-drop and configure) way of building user interfaces that many tools encourage you are likely to come across three design patterns called Model-View-Controller, Model-View-Presenter and Model-View-ViewModel. My question has three parts to it:
What issues do these patterns address?
How are they similar?
How are they different?
OUTPUT:answer:
Model-View-Controller (MVC), Model-View-Presenter (MVP), and Model-View-ViewModel (MVVM) are design patterns used to separate the concerns of a software application into separate, testable, and maintainable components.

Issues addressed:

MVC: Addresses the issue of separation of concerns and provides a clear structure for creating applications, allowing multiple developers to work on the same project.
MVP: Addresses the issue of having tight coupling between the view and the controller and reduces the dependencies between them.
MVVM: Addresses the issue of managing the state and behavior of the user interface in a scalable and maintainable way.
Similarities:

All three patterns separate the responsibilities of the application into different components.
All three patterns are used to build graphical user interfaces.
All three patterns aim to make the code more testable and maintainable.
Differences:

MVC: The controller updates the model and updates the view based on the changes in the model.
MVP: The presenter acts as an intermediary between the view and the model and updates the view based on the changes in the model.
MVVM: The view model updates the view based on changes in the model and handles user actions by updating the model. The view model also manages the state of the view.
In summary, MVC, MVP, and MVVM are different design patterns used to address different issues in software development, but they all aim to make the code more testable and maintainable.

INPUT:question:
Least Astonishment" and the Mutable Default Argument
Anyone tinkering with Python long enough has been bitten (or torn to pieces) by the following issue:
def foo(a=[]):
    a.append(5)
    return a
Python novices would expect this function called with no parameter to always return a list with only one element: [5]. The result is instead very different, and very astonishing (for a novice):
>>> foo()
[5]
>>> foo()
[5, 5]
>>> foo()
[5, 5, 5]
>>> foo()
[5, 5, 5, 5]
>>> foo()
A manager of mine once had his first encounter with this feature, and called it "a dramatic design flaw" of the language. I replied that the behavior had an underlying explanation, and it is indeed very puzzling and unexpected if you don't understand the internals. However, I was not able to answer (to myself) the following question: what is the reason for binding the default argument at function definition, and not at function execution? I doubt the experienced behavior has a practical use (who really used static variables in C, without breeding bugs?)
Edit:
Baczek made an interesting example. Together with most of your comments and Utaal's in particular, I elaborated further:
>>> def a():
...     print("a executed")
...     return []
... 
>>>            
>>> def b(x=a()):
...     x.append(5)
...     print(x)
... 
a executed
>>> b()
[5]
>>> b()
[5, 5]
To me, it seems that the design decision was relative to where to put the scope of parameters: inside the function, or "together" with it?
Doing the binding inside the function would mean that x is effectively bound to the specified default when the function is called, not defined, something that would present a deep flaw: the def line would be "hybrid" in the sense that part of the binding (of the function object) would happen at definition, and part (assignment of default parameters) at function invocation time.
The actual behavior is more consistent: everything of that line gets evaluated when that line is executed, meaning at function definition.
OUTPUT:answer: The reason for binding the default argument at function definition and not at function execution is to allow for efficient implementation of the language and consistency in the language design. The default value for an argument is evaluated when the function is defined and not re-evaluated every time the function is called. This is because the default argument is meant to be a static value and not a value that changes with each function call. This behavior makes the language more consistent, as all parts of a function definition are evaluated when the function is defined and not when it is executed. However, it can lead to unexpected results when the default argument is mutable, as demonstrated in the example you provided.

When to use LinkedList over ArrayList in Java?
I've always been one to simply use:
List<String> names = new ArrayList<>();
I use the interface as the type name for portability, so that when I ask questions such as this, I can rework my code.
When should LinkedList be used over ArrayList and vice-versa?
OUTPUT:answer:
In Java, the choice between ArrayList and LinkedList is primarily based on the operations you need to perform on the data structure.

ArrayList is backed by an array and provides constant-time access to elements by index. So, if you frequently need to access elements at random indices, or search for elements in the list, ArrayList is a good choice.

On the other hand, LinkedList is implemented as a linked list, so inserting or deleting elements in the middle of the list takes constant time on average, but accessing an element by index takes linear time. So, if you frequently add or remove elements in the middle of the list, LinkedList is a better choice.

In summary, ArrayList is better for frequently accessing elements by index, while LinkedList is better for frequently adding or removing elements in the middle of the list.

INPUT:question:
What is reflection and why is it useful?
What is reflection, and why is it useful?
I'm particularly interested in Java, but I assume the principles are the same in any language.
OUTPUT:answer:
Reflection is a feature in computer programming that allows a program to examine, inspect and manipulate its own structure, metadata, and behavior at runtime. In Java, the java.lang.reflect package provides the means for achieving reflection. Reflection is useful in a variety of situations, such as:

Dynamic Class Loading: Reflection allows you to load classes dynamically at runtime, which can be useful for plugin systems, among other things.

Debugging and Diagnostic Tools: Reflection provides a way for debugging and diagnostic tools to inspect the structure and behavior of a program.

Dynamic Class Generation: Reflection can be used to generate classes dynamically at runtime, which can be useful for code generation tools and other dynamic systems.

Reverse Engineering: Reflection can be used to inspect the structure and behavior of a class even if its source code is not available.

Overall, reflection provides a way for a program to inspect and manipulate its own structure, which can be useful in many different types of applications.

INPUT:question:
How to check if a column exists in a SQL Server table
I need to add a specific column if it does not exist. I have something like the following, but it always returns false:
IF EXISTS(SELECT *
          FROM   INFORMATION_SCHEMA.COLUMNS
          WHERE  TABLE_NAME = 'myTableName'
                 AND COLUMN_NAME = 'myColumnName') 
How can I check if a column exists in a table of the SQL Server database?
OUTPUT:answer:
To check if a column exists in a SQL Server table, you can use the following query:

sql
Copy code
IF EXISTS(SELECT * 
          FROM sys.columns 
          WHERE object_id = OBJECT_ID('myTableName') 
          AND name = 'myColumnName')
The sys.columns catalog view provides information about the columns in a database. The OBJECT_ID function returns the object ID of the specified table. If the query returns any rows, it means that the column exists.

INPUT:question:
Difference between static class and singleton pattern?
What real (i.e. practical) difference exists between a static class and a singleton pattern?
Both can be invoked without instantiation, both provide only one "Instance" and neither of them is thread-safe. Is there any other difference?
OUTPUT:answer:
Yes, there are some differences between a static class and a singleton pattern.

Inheritance: A static class cannot be inherited, whereas a singleton class can be inherited but it must be taken care that only one instance of the derived class is created.

Flexibility: A static class is less flexible as it cannot be extended, whereas a singleton class can be easily extended or modified.

Lazy Initialization: A singleton class can have a lazy initialization, which means that its instance is created only when it is needed. On the other hand, a static class is initialized when the program starts.

Dependency Injection: A singleton class can be used in Dependency Injection, whereas a static class cannot be used in DI as it cannot be instantiated.

In summary, while both static classes and singletons serve the purpose of providing a single instance, singletons offer more flexibility and are more suited for complex cases where inheritance and lazy initialization are required.

INPUT:question:
When should I use 'self' over '$this'?
In PHP 5, what is the difference between using self and $this?
When is each appropriate?
OUTPUT:answer:
In PHP 5, self and $this are used to refer to the current class. The difference is that self is used to refer to static properties and methods, while $this is used to refer to non-static properties and methods.

self should be used when you want to access a static property or method, as static properties and methods belong to the class, not an instance of the class.

$this should be used when you want to access a non-static property or method, as non-static properties and methods belong to an instance of the class.

INPUT:question:
How does Git handle symbolic links?
If I have a file or directory that is a symbolic link and I commit it to a Git repository, what happens to it?
I would assume that it leaves it as a symbolic link until the file is deleted and then if you pull the file back from an old version it just creates a normal file.
What does it do when I delete the file it references? Does it just commit the dangling link?
OUTPUT:answer: Git treats symbolic links as a special file type and stores the link target as a file. When you commit a symbolic link to a Git repository, it stores the symbolic link as is, and the link target is not followed. If you delete the file that the symbolic link references, the symbolic link will become a "dangling link", and Git will still commit it as is. When you checkout an older version of the repository, the symbolic link will be restored, but if the link target no longer exists, it will remain a "dangling link".

INPUT:question:
Comments in Markdown
How do you write a comment in Markdown, i.e. text that is not rendered in the HTML output? I found nothing on the Markdown project.
OUTPUT:answer:
In Markdown, comments are not directly supported, as the syntax is intended to be simple and straightforward. However, there are some workarounds to add comments to a Markdown document:

HTML comments: You can use HTML comments to add comments to a Markdown document. For example, <!-- This is a comment -->

Raw text: You can also write comments as raw text, which will not be rendered in the HTML output. For example, This is a comment

Note: These comments will only be visible in the source Markdown file, and will not be included in the HTML output generated from the Markdown.

# Ignore everything:

OUTPUT:answer:
You can use the .gitignore file to ignore everything by specifying a wildcard character * on its own line, and then specify the exceptions you want to track with Git by listing them each on their own line, without a preceding ! or # symbol:

yaml

# Ignore everything:
*

# Do not ignore these files:
!script.pl
!template.latex
This way, the * wildcard will match all files in the repository, but the exceptions will be tracked by Git. Note that the exceptions must be listed one per line and should not have any wildcard characters themselves.
