INPUT:question:
What is dependency injection?
There have been several questions already posted with specific questions about dependency injection, such as when to use it and what frameworks are there for it. However,
What is dependency injection and when/why should or shouldn't it be used?
OUTPUT:answer:
Dependency Injection (DI) is a software design pattern that enables a class to decouple its dependencies from the actual objects that provide them. It allows an object to receive its dependencies from an external source, instead of creating them internally. This makes the code more flexible, reusable, and easier to test, since the dependencies can be changed without modifying the code that uses them.

When should it be used?

When the components in a software application are tightly coupled and difficult to maintain.
When you want to isolate the effects of changes in one component from others.
When you want to improve testability of your code by allowing dependencies to be swapped or mocked.
When shouldn't it be used?

When the application is small and simple. Overusing DI can make the code more complex and harder to understand.
When the dependencies are hardcoded and unlikely to change in the future.
When performance is a critical factor, as resolving dependencies through DI can add some overhead.

INPUT:question:
How do you merge two Git repositories?
Consider the following scenario:
I have developed a small experimental project A in its own Git repo. It has now matured, and I'd like A to be part of larger project B, which has its own big repository. I'd now like to add A as a subdirectory of B.
How do I merge A into B, without losing history on any side?
OUTPUT:answer:
To merge two Git repositories, you can follow these steps:

Clone the repository B where you want to add the repository A as a subdirectory:
bash
Copy code
git clone <repo_B_url>
cd <repo_B>
Add repository A as a remote in repository B:
php
Copy code
git remote add -f <remote_name> <repo_A_url>
Checkout a branch in repository B to merge the contents of repository A:
css
Copy code
git checkout -b <branch_name>
Use git merge or git subtree to merge the contents of repository A into the branch in repository B, making sure to specify the directory where the contents of repository A should be placed:
sql
Copy code
# using `git merge`
git merge --allow-unrelated-histories <remote_name>/<branch_name>

# using `git subtree`
git subtree add --prefix=<subdir> <remote_name>/<branch_name>
Push the changes to repository B:
perl
Copy code
git push origin <branch_name>
Note: the git subtree method is preferred if you want to maintain the separate histories of repositories A and B, while the git merge method will combine the histories of the two repositories.

OUTPUT:answer: Accessing a column in a Pandas DataFrame using df.column_name returns a Series, but it is not actually an attribute of the DataFrame. On the other hand, columns in a DataFrame can be treated as keys in a dictionary, and so can be deleted using the del statement with the dictionary-style indexing, as in del df['column_name']. The del statement only works for attributes and not items accessed using indexing or other methods like accessing a Series.

  when 2
    "Tuesday"
  when 3
    "Wednesday"
  when 4
    "Thursday"
  when 5
    "Friday"
  when 6

end

INPUT:question:
Difference between "git add -A" and "git add ."
What is the difference between git add [--all | -A] and git add .?
OUTPUT:answer:
The difference between git add -A and git add . lies in what changes they stage for commit.

git add -A stages all changes, including modifications and deletions, in the entire repository.

git add . stages only changes that are new files or modifications, but not deletions, in the current directory and its subdirectories.

So, if you want to stage all changes, use git add -A, while if you want to stage only new or modified files, use git add ..

OUTPUT:answer:
You can fix a detached HEAD state by creating a new branch that points to the current commit and checkout the new branch.

Here's the steps to do it:

Run git log to find the commit hash for the current detached HEAD state.
Run git branch newbranchname to create a new branch pointing to the current commit.
Run git checkout newbranchname to switch to the new branch.
Alternatively, if you want to discard all changes and start over with the latest version in the remote repository, you can run:

Run git fetch origin to retrieve the latest version from the remote repository.
Run git reset --hard origin/master to reset the local repository to the latest version in the remote repository.

INPUT:question:
How do I find and restore a deleted file in a Git repository?

How do I find the commit that deleted a given filename?
How do I restore that file back into my working copy?
OUTPUT:answer:
To find the commit that deleted a given file, you can use the command:

css
Copy code
git log --diff-filter=D --summary
This will show a list of all commits that deleted files, along with a summary of the changes in each commit. You can look for the file you deleted and note the commit hash for that change.

To restore the file, you can checkout the previous version of the file using the commit hash from the above command:

php
Copy code
git checkout <commit_hash>^ -- <file_name>
This will restore the file as it was in the commit before it was deleted. You can then add the file and make a new commit to complete the restore process.

OUTPUT:answer:
To check if a key exists in a JavaScript object, you can use the "in" operator or the object's "hasOwnProperty()" method. For example:

sql
Copy code
let obj = { key1: "value1", key2: "value2" };

// using "in" operator
console.log("key1" in obj); // true
console.log("key3" in obj); // false

// using hasOwnProperty() method
console.log(obj.hasOwnProperty("key1")); // true
console.log(obj.hasOwnProperty("key3")); // false
If you try to access a key that doesn't exist in an object, it will return undefined and not throw an error. For example:

javascript
Copy code
let obj = { key1: "value1" };

console.log(obj.key2); // undefined

To append to a file in Python, you can open the file in append mode ("a") and write to it using the write() or writelines() method.

Here's an example:

python
Copy code
with open("file.txt", "a") as file:
    file.write("text to append")
In this example, the file will be opened in append mode (the "a" in "a") and the string "text to append" will be added to the end of the file. The with statement is used to ensure that the file is properly closed after the block of code is executed.

The Java language specification defines the behavior of the compound assignment operators such as +=, -=, *=, /=. They perform an implicit cast to the type of the target variable (left-hand side) if the type of the expression on the right-hand side is not exactly the same.

So in your example, i += j; is equivalent to i = (int) (i + j);, where the result of i + j is cast to an int. Note that if the result of the addition overflows the range of int, the behavior is undefined, as it would result in a loss of precision.

INPUT:question:
How can I create an executable/runnable JAR with dependencies using Maven?
I want to package my project in a single executable JAR for distribution.
How can I make a Maven project package all dependency JARs into my output JAR?
OUTPUT:answer:
You can create an executable JAR with dependencies using Maven by using the Maven Assembly Plugin. The plugin allows you to package the project and its dependencies into a single executable JAR file.

To use the Maven Assembly Plugin, you will need to add the following to your project's pom.xml file:

php
Copy code
<build>
  <plugins>
    <plugin>
      <artifactId>maven-assembly-plugin</artifactId>
      <version>3.3.0</version>
      <configuration>
        <descriptorRefs>
          <descriptorRef>jar-with-dependencies</descriptorRef>
        </descriptorRefs>
        <archive>
          <manifest>
            <mainClass>com.example.MainClass</mainClass>
          </manifest>
        </archive>
      </configuration>
      <executions>
        <execution>
          <id>make-assembly</id>
          <phase>package</phase>
          <goals>
            <goal>single</goal>
          </goals>
        </execution>
      </executions>
    </plugin>
  </plugins>
</build>
In this example, com.example.MainClass is the fully-qualified name of the main class of your project.

Once the plugin is added, you can run mvn package to build the executable JAR with dependencies. The output JAR file will be located in the target directory of your project.

INPUT:question:
What is a JavaBean exactly?
I understood, I think, that a "Bean" is a Java-class with properties and getters/setters. 
As much as I understand, it is the equivalent of a C struct. Is that true?
Also, is there a real syntactic difference between a JavaBean and a regular class? 
Is there any special definition or an Interface?
Basically, why is there a term for this?
Also what does the Serializable interface mean?
OUTPUT:answer:
A JavaBean is a Java class that follows a certain coding convention, including following rules such as:

The class must have a default (no-arg) constructor
Properties are defined with private fields, and public getter and setter methods
The class must implement the Serializable interface
The term "JavaBean" is used to describe a Java class that adheres to this convention and can be used as an object for data storage, manipulation, and transfer between parts of a software system.

The Serializable interface is a marker interface that indicates that an object can be written to, or read from, a stream. This interface has no methods and is used to allow Java objects to be transferred over networks or stored in a persistent storage media such as a file system.

JavaBeans are not equivalent to C structs, as JavaBeans have the additional requirements for constructors, getter/setter methods, and the Serializable interface.

There is no strict syntactic difference between a JavaBean and a regular Java class. The term "JavaBean" is a convention that implies certain coding practices, while a regular Java class can follow any coding conventions or practices.

OUTPUT:answer: Move semantics is a feature in C++ that allows for efficient and safe transfer of ownership of resources, such as memory or file handles, from one object to another. Instead of copying the data, which can be slow and wasteful, move semantics allows the data to be moved from one object to another, leaving the original object in a valid but unspecified state. This can significantly improve the performance and efficiency of code, especially when working with large or complex objects.

OUTPUT:answer:
O(log n) means that the growth rate of the algorithm is logarithmic. It means that the size of the input affects the growth of the algorithm such that the amount of operations performed increases logarithmically with the size of the input.

For example, when you are searching for an item in a sorted array using a binary search algorithm, you keep dividing the search space in half until you find the item or determine that it is not in the array. The number of operations required to find the item is proportional to the logarithm of the size of the array. This is why binary search is considered to have a time complexity of O(log n).

In the case of the height of a complete binary tree, it means that the height of the tree is proportional to the logarithm of the total number of nodes in the tree. This is because in a complete binary tree, the number of nodes in each level is multiplied by 2 as you move down the levels. The logarithmic relationship between the height of the tree and the number of nodes ensures that searching and traversing operations in the tree are efficient.

What is the difference between CMD and ENTRYPOINT in a Dockerfile?

and for ENTRYPOINT:
An ENTRYPOINT helps you to configure a container that you can run as an executable.

OUTPUT:answer: CMD and ENTRYPOINT serve similar purposes but there is a difference in their behavior. CMD provides default command arguments that can be overridden by command line arguments passed to docker run or specified in the Compose file. On the other hand, ENTRYPOINT configures a container as an executable and the specified command is always run when the container is started, with any command line arguments passed to docker run being passed to the ENTRYPOINT as arguments. In essence, CMD is meant to be used as arguments for a command specified in the ENTRYPOINT.

INPUT:question:
How do I change permissions for a folder and its subfolders/files?
How do I change the permissions of a folder and all its subfolders and files?
This only applies to the /opt/lampp/htdocs folder, not its contents:
chmod 775 /opt/lampp/htdocs
How do I set chmod 755 for all of the  /opt/lampp/htdocs folder's current contents, as well as automatically in the future for new folders/files created under it?
OUTPUT:answer:
To change permissions for a folder and its subfolders/files, you can use the following command:

bash
Copy code
chmod -R 755 /opt/lampp/htdocs
The -R option stands for "recursive" and it will apply the permission changes to the folder and all its subdirectories and files. The 755 in the command represents the permissions for the owner (user), the group, and other users respectively, in binary format.

To set 755 permissions for new folders and files automatically, you can use the umask command. For example:

bash
Copy code
umask 002
This sets the default file creation mask to 002, which will result in files being created with permissions 755 (i.e., rwxr-xr-x). Note that the umask command is typically set in the shell startup script (e.g., ~/.bashrc) to persist across sessions.

rupshaahiri12@gmail.com
How can I remove a commit on GitHub?
I "accidentally" pushed a commit to GitHub.
Is it possible to remove this commit?
I want to revert my GitHub repository as it was before this commit.

To remove a commit from GitHub, you need to perform a "force push".
Here's how you can do it:

Clone the repository to your local machine
Checkout the branch you want to remove the commit from
Run the command git log to find the hash of the commit you want to remove
Run the command git rebase -i <hash of the previous commit>
In the editor that opens, change the word "pick" to "drop" next to the commit you want to remove
Save the file and close the editor
Run the command git push -f origin <branch name>
Note: Be cautious when force pushing, as it can overwrite the remote branch and may cause conflicts for other collaborators who have already pulled the branch.

OUTPUT:answer:
In Android, a Context class is a core component that provides access to various resources and services, such as the application environment, activity environment, system services, and more. A Context can be thought of as a handle to the system or an interface to global information about an application environment.

A Context object is required for most Android API calls, and can be used to retrieve information about the activity, service, or application in which it is running. Some common uses of Context include accessing system services (such as the LayoutInflater, NotificationManager, and ActivityManager), starting activities, or accessing resources.

In general, a Context should be passed as a parameter to methods that need access to information about the environment in which they are running. The Context can be obtained in various ways, such as by calling getContext() on an activity, or getApplicationContext() to obtain the application context.

INPUT:question:
How do you stash an untracked file?

OUTPUT:answer:
You can stash untracked files by using the "--include-untracked" option with the "git stash" command. This will stash all changes, including new, modified and untracked files.

Here's an example:

ruby

INPUT:question:
What is the difference between `margin` and `padding` in CSS?
What is the difference between margin and padding in CSS?
In what kind of situations:
both work.
only margin is appropriate.
only padding is appropriate.
OUTPUT:answer:
Margin and padding are CSS properties used to create space around HTML elements.

Margin refers to the outer space of an element and is used to create space around an element, outside of any defined borders.

Padding, on the other hand, refers to the inner space of an element and is used to create space between an element's content and its border.

Both can be used in a variety of situations but here are some examples of specific situations where one is more appropriate than the other:

Only padding is appropriate when you want to create space within an element, for example, to separate the text from the border of a text box.
Only margin is appropriate when you want to create space outside of an element, for example, to separate two block-level elements.
Both can be used in situations where you want to create space around an element, it just depends on the desired outcome and how much space you want to create.

Postman and JavaScript code running in a browser are subject to different restrictions when making cross-origin HTTP requests due to the Same-Origin Policy and Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) restrictions. When making an HTTP request from JavaScript running in a browser, it is subject to the Same-Origin Policy and CORS restrictions, which disallow requests from a different origin (domain, protocol, or port) unless the response from the server includes the "Access-Control-Allow-Origin" header. However, when making requests from Postman, it is not subject to the same restrictions, allowing it to make cross-origin requests without encountering the "No 'Access-Control-Allow-Origin' header is present on the requested resource" error.

Here's an example of sorting a dictionary in ascending order by value:

INPUT:question:
Should I use Vagrant or Docker for creating an isolated environment?
I use Ubuntu for development and deployment and have a need for creating an isolated environment. 
I am considering either Vagrant or Docker for this purpose. What are the pros and cons, or how do these solutions compare?
OUTPUT:answer:
Vagrant and Docker are both popular tools for creating isolated environments, but they have different purposes and design goals:

Vagrant:

Pros:

Easy to use and set up, with a user-friendly interface.
Provides a full virtual machine environment that can run any software or OS, which makes it easier to match production environments.
Offers greater flexibility and configurability, as you have full access to the virtual machine.
Cons:

More resource-intensive, as it runs a full virtual machine that needs its own resources such as CPU, memory, and disk space.
Slower to start and stop, as it takes time to spin up and shut down a full virtual machine.
Docker:

Pros:

Lightweight, as it uses containers instead of full virtual machines, which requires fewer resources.
Fast to start and stop, as containers can be created and destroyed quickly.
Good for microservices architecture, where each service can run in its own isolated container.
Cons:

Not as flexible as Vagrant, as you don't have full access to the host operating system.
More challenging to set up and use, as it requires a deeper understanding of containers and the underlying technology.
In conclusion, the choice between Vagrant and Docker depends on the specific requirements of your project and your preferences as a developer. If you need a more flexible and configurable environment, and don't mind the overhead of running a full virtual machine, then Vagrant might be a better choice. If you're looking for a more lightweight solution that is fast to start and stop, and that can be used for microservices architecture, then Docker is the way to go.

INPUT:question:
What is tail recursion?
Whilst starting to learn lisp, I've come across the term tail-recursive. What does it mean exactly?
OUTPUT:answer: Tail recursion is a special case of recursion where the recursive call is the last statement executed in the function. This means that the function does not have any other operations to perform after making the recursive call, and the result of the recursive call can be immediately returned as the result of the function. This allows the function to return its result without consuming additional stack space, as the current stack frame can be reused for the next iteration of the recursion. This can result in much more efficient use of stack space and can prevent stack overflow errors in cases where a normal, non-tail-recursive implementation would run out of stack space.

INPUT:question:
Should I use the datetime or timestamp data type in MySQL?
Would you recommend using a datetime or a timestamp field, and why (using MySQL)? 
I'm working with PHP on the server side.
OUTPUT:answer:
It depends on your use case. If you need to store a specific date and time that may be affected by time zones or daylight savings, then use the datetime data type. If you need to store a timestamp that is based on the current time, you should use the timestamp data type.

The timestamp field is automatically set to the current date and time if no value is provided for that field, and it is automatically updated every time the row is updated. The datetime field must be set explicitly by the user, and does not automatically update.

In general, timestamp is recommended for keeping track of when a record was created or last updated, while datetime is recommended for storing dates and times that are entered by users, such as a birthdate or an event date and time.

INPUT:question:
What is the difference between a process and a thread?
What is the technical difference between a process and a thread?
I get the feeling a word like 'process' is overused and there are also hardware and software threads. How about light-weight processes in languages like Erlang? Is there a definitive reason to use one term over the other?
OUTPUT:answer:
A process is an instance of a program in execution, while a thread is a lightweight, independent unit of processing within a process.

A process can contain multiple threads, which run concurrently and share the process's resources such as memory and file descriptors. A thread, on the other hand, has its own execution stack but shares the same data space with other threads in the same process.

In terms of hardware threads, these refer to the physical threads of execution in a multi-threaded processor, whereas software threads are the threads implemented by the operating system or application. Light-weight processes, as in the case of Erlang, are similar to threads but offer additional features such as isolated memory spaces and message-passing concurrency.

The choice between using the term "process" or "thread" can depend on the context and the level of abstraction one wants to convey. Generally, "process" is used to describe the larger unit of execution while "thread" is used to describe the smaller, concurrent unit of processing within a process.

INPUT:question:
How do I safely merge a Git branch into master?
A new branch from master is created, we call it test.
There are several developers who either commit to master or create other branches and later merge into master.
Let's say work on test is taking several days and you want to continuously keep test updated with commits inside master.
I would do git pull origin master from test. 
Question 1: Is this the right approach?  Other developers could have easily worked on same files as I have worked btw.
My work on test is done and I am ready to merge it back to master. Here are the two ways I can think of:
A:  
git checkout test
git pull origin master
git push origin test
git checkout master
git pull origin test 
B: 
git checkout test
git pull origin master
git checkout master
git merge test
I am not using --rebase because from my understanding, rebase will get the changes from master and stack mine on top of that hence it could overwrite changes other people made.
Question 2: Which one of these two methods is right?  What is the difference there?
The goal in all of this is to keep my test branch updated with the things happening in master and later I could merge them back into master hoping to keep the timeline as linear as possible.
OUTPUT:answer:
Answer to Question 1:

The right approach to keep the test branch updated with changes made in master is to run git checkout test followed by git pull origin master.

Answer to Question 2:

Both of the methods described are correct and will result in the test branch being merged into master.

Method A:
This method involves first pushing the changes in the test branch to the remote repository, then pulling the changes from the remote repository into the local master branch.

Method B:
This method involves first merging the test branch into the local master branch, then pushing the changes to the remote repository.

The difference between the two methods is that in Method A, the changes from the test branch are first pushed to the remote repository and then pulled into the local master branch, whereas in Method B, the changes are first merged into the local master branch and then pushed to the remote repository.

The goal in either method is to keep the test branch updated with the master branch and to maintain a linear timeline.

INPUT:question:
What does " 2>&1 " mean?
To combine stderr and stdout into the stdout stream, we append this to a command:
2>&1
e.g. to see the first few errors from compiling g++ main.cpp:
g++ main.cpp 2>&1 | head
What does 2>&1 mean, in detail?
OUTPUT:answer: The expression "2>&1" in Unix-like systems means to redirect the standard error (stderr) stream to the same location as the standard output (stdout) stream. The "2" refers to stderr (file descriptor 2), while the "&1" refers to stdout (file descriptor 1). So, "2>&1" is saying "redirect stderr to wherever stdout is currently going".

lua

The above command will cache your credentials for 15 minutes. If you want to increase the cache time, you can set the credential.helper to cache --timeout=3600, where 3600 is the number of seconds you want to cache the credentials for (e.g., 1 hour).

super() is used to refer to the parent class, it makes it easier to call the __init__ method of the parent class in multiple inheritance scenarios, where a class might inherit from multiple base classes.

The difference between using Base.__init__(self) and super().__init__() is that Base.__init__(self) directly calls the __init__ method of the Base class, whereas super().__init__() calls the next class in the method resolution order. When the ChildB class inherits from the Base class, super().__init__() will call Base.__init__(self), but if there are other classes in the method resolution order, super().__init__() will call the next class's __init__ method instead.

The difference in performance between the two loops is due to cache behavior. When multiple arrays are stored in contiguous memory, as in the first loop, accessing them can result in cache eviction. That is, as the processor tries to access elements of different arrays stored in contiguous memory, some elements of arrays may get evicted from the cache, leading to a cache miss and resulting in slower access. On the other hand, when arrays are stored in separate memory, there is less chance of cache eviction, leading to faster access. Additionally, the cache can handle data in the form of cache lines, and accessing data in separate arrays can result in more cache-friendly access patterns. This can result in better performance.

Yes, there are significant differences between "implements Runnable" and "extends Thread" in Java.

The primary difference is that extending the Thread class creates a new class that is a subclass of Thread, and therefore can only be used to create objects of that class, whereas implementing the Runnable interface allows the creation of objects that can be passed as a target to a Thread object.

This means that if you extend the Thread class, you cannot extend any other class, as Java does not support multiple inheritance. On the other hand, implementing the Runnable interface allows you to take advantage of multiple inheritance, as a class can implement multiple interfaces.

Another difference is that it is generally considered to be better practice to implement the Runnable interface because it leads to cleaner, more modular code. Additionally, the Runnable interface is more flexible, as it allows you to pass a single Runnable object to multiple threads.

In summary, if you want to create a reusable component that can be run as a thread, use the Runnable interface. If you need to create a new type of thread, extend the Thread class.

INPUT:question:
Config Error: This configuration section cannot be used at this path
I've encountered an error deploying a site to a server.  When trying to load the home page, or access authentication on the new site in IIS, I get the error:
  Config Error: This configuration section cannot be used at this path.
  This happens when the section is locked at a parent level. Locking is
  either by default (overrideModeDefault="Deny"), or set explicitly by a
  location tag with overrideMode="Deny" or the legacy
  allowOverride="false".
More detail can be found here, in Scenario 7 matches my hex error code.
The solution given on the linked site above is to set Allow for overrideModeDefault in the section mentioned in my error, in the applicationHost.config file.  In my case,  under Security in system.webServer.  But if I look at the applicationHost.config on my local computer, where the site is properly deployed already, that section is set to Deny.
If this solution is correct, how is my local instance running just fine with the same web.config?  According to my applicationHost.config, that section should be locked, but it's not.  I'd prefer to not change the applicationHost.config file, because there are many other sites running on that server.  Is there another solution?
OUTPUT:answer:
The issue you're encountering is due to the fact that certain sections in your web.config file are locked at a parent level in IIS. This prevents you from making changes to those sections and can result in the error you're seeing.

To resolve this issue without modifying the applicationHost.config file, you can try the following:

Make the changes to the web.config file at the individual website level instead of the server level
Change the section's overrideMode to Allow in the web.config file for the specific website.
If you still face the same error, you can try searching the web.config file for the locked section and see if it is set to "Deny" anywhere else. If so, change it to "Allow" to allow the changes to take effect.

', '  File "test_python.py", line 8, in <module>
    s = i.next()
', 'StopIteration
']
What can I do in order to catch the 'stop iteration' exception and break a while
loop properly?
An example of why such a thing may be needed is shown below as pseudocode.
State machine:
s = ""
while True :
  if state is STATE_CODE :
    if "//" in s :
      tokens.add( TOKEN_COMMENT, s.split( "//" )[1] )
      state = STATE_COMMENT
    else :
      tokens.add( TOKEN_CODE, s )
  if state is STATE_COMMENT :
    if "//" in s :
      tokens.append( TOKEN_COMMENT, s.split( "//" )[1] )
    else
      state = STATE_CODE
      # Re-evaluate same line
      continue
  try :
    s = i.next()
  except StopIteration :
    break

You can use a for loop instead of a while loop to iterate over the elements in list_of_ints, and use the else clause to run the code that follows the try block in case no exception is raised. Here's the updated code:

scss
Copy code

iterator = iter(list_of_ints)
element = None
for element in iterator:
    print(element)
else:
    print("done")
The else clause of a for loop is executed if the loop terminates normally (i.e., without encountering a break statement), and in this case, it runs the code that follows the try block in the original code. The StopIteration exception will be raised automatically when all elements have been iterated over.

OUTPUT:answer:
Yes, you can check if a variable exists in Python using the globals() or locals() functions.

The globals() function returns a dictionary of the current global symbol table, which includes all global variables. To check if a variable exists, you can check if it is in the globals() dictionary:

python
Copy code
if 'myVar' in globals():
    # Do something.
The locals() function returns a dictionary of the current local symbol table, which includes all local variables. To check if a variable exists, you can check if it is in the locals() dictionary:

python
Copy code
if 'myVar' in locals():
    # Do something.
Keep in mind that the locals() function only checks the current scope, so if myVar is a global variable, it will only be found in the globals() dictionary.

How can I fix this issue?
OUTPUT:answer:
To properly force a Git push, use the following command:

python
Copy code
git push --force-with-lease
This command allows you to overwrite the remote branch, but only if it hasn't been updated by someone else. If someone else has pushed changes to the remote branch, this command will fail and you'll need to pull the latest changes and resolve the conflicts before pushing again.

Alternatively, if you are sure that you want to overwrite the remote branch and don't care about losing any remote changes, use the following command:

css
Copy code
git push --force
But be aware that this can lead to data loss if other people are working on the same branch.

OUTPUT:answer:
To list the tables in an attached SQLite database file, you can use the following SQL command:

sql
Copy code
SELECT name FROM sqlite_master WHERE type='table';
To list the rows within a table, you can use the following SQL command, replacing <table_name> with the actual name of the table:

sql
Copy code
SELECT * FROM <table_name>;
Note that sqlite_master is a system table in SQLite that contains information about all tables and indices in a database. The type column in sqlite_master is used to differentiate between tables and other objects (e.g. indices, views, etc.).

For an update request using the HTTP PUT method, the typical response status codes are 200 (OK) or 204 (No Content) if the update was successful.

INPUT:question:
How does the vim "write with sudo" trick work?
Many of you have probably seen the command that allows you to write on a file that needs root permission, even when you forgot to open vim with sudo:
:w !sudo tee %
The thing is that I don't get what is exactly happening here.
I have already figured this:
w is for this
                                                        *:w_c* *:write_c*
:[range]w[rite] [++opt] !{cmd}
                        Execute {cmd} with [range] lines as standard input
                        (note the space in front of the '!').  {cmd} is
                        executed like with ":!{cmd}", any '!' is replaced with
                        the previous command |:!|.
so it passes all the lines as standard input.
The !sudo tee part calls tee with administrator privileges.
For all to make sense, the % should output the filename (as a parameter for tee), but I can't find references on the help for this behavior.
tl;dr Could someone help me dissect this command?
OUTPUT:answer: The Vim command :w !sudo tee % writes the contents of the buffer to a file with superuser privileges. It works by using the Vim :write (:w) command to pipe the contents of the buffer to the shell command sudo tee %. The % symbol in this command is a special symbol in Vim that represents the current file name. The tee command writes the input it receives from standard input (which is the contents of the buffer in this case) to both the standard output and a file. By using sudo, the tee command is run with superuser privileges, allowing it to write to files that are normally only writable by the root user.

INPUT:question:
How to deal with persistent storage (e.g. databases) in Docker
How do people deal with persistent storage for your Docker containers?
I am currently using this approach: build the image, e.g. for PostgreSQL, and then start the container with
docker run --volumes-from c0dbc34fd631 -d app_name/postgres
IMHO, that has the drawback, that I must not ever (by accident) delete container "c0dbc34fd631".
Another idea would be to mount host volumes "-v" into the container, however, the userid within the container does not necessarily match the userid from the host, and then permissions might be messed up.
Note: Instead of --volumes-from 'cryptic_id' you can also use --volumes-from my-data-container where my-data-container is a name you assigned to a data-only container, e.g. docker run --name my-data-container ... (see the accepted answer)
OUTPUT:answer:
The most common ways to deal with persistent storage in Docker are:

Data Volumes: This involves mounting a host directory as a data volume within the container. For example:
bash
Copy code
docker run -v /host/directory:/container/directory -d app_name/postgres
Data Volume Containers: This involves creating a data-only container and mounting its data volume to another container. For example:
kotlin
Copy code
docker create -v /data --name my-data-container busybox
docker run --volumes-from my-data-container -d app_name/postgres
Network Attached Storage (NAS) or Storage Area Network (SAN): In this approach, the data storage is managed by a separate storage system that is accessible over the network.
Note that it is important to consider the durability and reliability of the storage solution based on your application requirements.

Python `if x is not None` or `if not x is None`?
I've always thought of the if not x is None version to be more clear, but Google's style guide and PEP-8 both use if x is not None. Are there any minor performance differences (I'm assuming not), and is there any case where one really doesn't fit (making the other a clear winner for my convention)?*
*I'm referring to any singleton, rather than just None.
...to compare singletons like
None. Use is  or is not.
OUTPUT:answer:
In Python, there is no difference in performance between if x is not None and if not x is None. Both are equivalent and can be used interchangeably.

The recommended style according to PEP 8 is if x is not None, as it is more readable and aligns with the recommended usage of the is operator for testing for object identity. On the other hand, if not x is None may be less readable for some people, as it requires a double negative (not and is) to achieve the same result.

So, the best practice is to use if x is not None for readability and to align with PEP 8 and other common Python style guides.

INPUT:question:
What is the difference between const and readonly in C#?
What is the difference between const and readonly in C#? 
When would you use one over the other?
OUTPUT:answer:
In C#, const and readonly are used to declare variables whose values cannot be changed after they are assigned. However, there are some key differences between the two:

    const is a compile-time constant and its value must be known at compile time. It is used for values that never change.

    readonly is a runtime constant and its value can be set at runtime. It is used for values that may change, but only through a constructor or a method.

When choosing between const and readonly, use const for values that are known at compile time and never change. Use readonly for values that may change, but only through a constructor or a method.

Difference between git stash pop and git stash apply
I've been using git stash pop for quite some time. I recently found out about the git stash apply command. When I tried it out, it seemed to work the same as git stash pop. 
What is the difference between git stash pop and git stash apply?
OUTPUT:answer:
The main difference between git stash pop and git stash apply is the way they handle the stashed changes once they have been reapplied.

git stash pop will reapply the stashed changes and then drop (remove) the stash from your stash list. This means that the changes will no longer be stored in your stash, and if you want to reapply them again later, you will need to stash them again.

git stash apply, on the other hand, will reapply the stashed changes but leave the stash in your stash list. This means that the stash will remain stored in your repository, and you can reapply the changes later by using the git stash apply command again.

In summary, if you want to reapply the stashed changes and then drop the stash, use git stash pop. If you want to reapply the stashed changes and keep the stash, use git stash apply.

How do I prompt for Yes/No/Cancel input in a Linux shell script?
I want to pause input in a shell script, and prompt the user for choices.
The standard Yes, No, or Cancel type question.
How do I accomplish this in a typical bash prompt?
OUTPUT:answer:
You can use the read command to prompt for input in a Linux shell script and use an if statement to check the value of the input against different options to determine the next step. Here's an example:

bash

#!/bin/bash

echo "Do you want to proceed? (y/n/c)"
read answer
if [ "$answer" == "y" ]; then
  # do something if the answer is "yes"
  echo "Yes"
elif [ "$answer" == "n" ]; then
  # do something if the answer is "no"
  echo "No"
elif [ "$answer" == "c" ]; then
  # do something if the answer is "cancel"
  echo "Cancel"
else
  # do something if the answer is something else
  echo "Invalid input"
fi

The script prompts the user with the text "Do you want to proceed? (y/n/c)" and waits for their input. The value of the input is stored in the variable answer, which is then compared against different options in the if statement. The appropriate action is taken depending on the value of the input.

INPUT:question:
Compiling an application for use in highly radioactive environments
We are compiling an embedded C++ application that is deployed in a shielded device in an environment bombarded with ionizing radiation. We are using GCC and cross-compiling for ARM. When deployed, our application generates some erroneous data and crashes more often than we would like. The hardware is designed for this environment, and our application has run on this platform for several years.
Are there changes we can make to our code, or compile-time improvements that can be made to identify/correct soft errors and memory-corruption caused by single event upsets? Have any other developers had success in reducing the harmful effects of soft errors on a long-running application?
OUTPUT:answer:
There are several ways to address single event upsets (SEUs) in software when deploying in highly radioactive environments:

    Error Correction Codes (ECC): ECC is a powerful technique for detecting and correcting soft errors. You can implement ECC at the memory level, and also at the processor level. ECC can detect and correct many types of memory errors.

    Checkpoint/Restart: One way to handle SEUs is to periodically checkpoint the state of the application and restart it if an error is detected. This allows the application to continue running, even if there are errors.

    Code Hardening: Another way to reduce the effects of SEUs is to harden the code. This can be done by implementing techniques such as stack protection, address space randomization, and read-only data segments.

    Avoiding Dynamic Memory Allocation: Dynamic memory allocation can cause problems in an environment that is susceptible to SEUs. One way to reduce the effects of SEUs is to avoid dynamic memory allocation and use statically allocated memory instead.

    Use Robust Libraries: You can also use robust libraries that are designed to handle SEUs. For example, the Boost C++ Libraries include a number of libraries that are designed to handle SEUs, including a robust implementation of the standard C++ string class.

It's important to remember that no single solution is guaranteed to be effective in all cases, so a combination of the above approaches may be necessary. Additionally, it's important to thoroughly test your application in a simulated environment that emulates the effects of ionizing radiation to identify and address potential problems before deployment.

INPUT:question:
What does T&& (double ampersand) mean in C++11?
I've been looking into some of the new features of C++11 and one I've noticed is the double ampersand in declaring variables, like T&& var.
For a start, what is this beast called? I wish Google would allow us to search for punctuation like this.
What exactly does it mean?
At first glance, it appears to be a double reference (like the C-style double pointers T** var), but I'm having a hard time thinking of a use case for that.
OUTPUT:answer:
C++11, T&& is called an rvalue reference. It's used to identify rvalue (temporary) objects, which can be optimized differently than lvalue (permanent) objects.

An rvalue reference provides a way to bind to temporary objects, allowing for more efficient transfer of resources, such as objects with dynamic memory allocation. The move constructor, for example, can be defined to take an rvalue reference as an argument, allowing it to transfer the ownership of a temporary object to a newly created object, rather than copying it.

In short, T&& is a useful tool in C++11 for improving performance and avoiding unnecessary copying of objects, especially for large and complex objects.

INPUT:question:
What's the difference between UTF-8 and UTF-8 with BOM?
What's different between UTF-8 and UTF-8 with BOM? Which is better?
OUTPUT:answer:
UTF-8 is a character encoding that represents each character as a sequence of 1 to 4 bytes. It's the most widely used encoding for the Web and has become the dominant character encoding for the transfer of text data.

UTF-8 with BOM (Byte Order Mark) is the same as UTF-8, but it starts with the three-byte BOM sequence EF BB BF that serves as a marker for the start of the file and as an indicator of the byte order of the encoded characters.

There is no significant difference between UTF-8 and UTF-8 with BOM in terms of the representation of characters. The difference lies in the use of the BOM, which can be helpful in some cases but not necessary in others.

Whether UTF-8 or UTF-8 with BOM is better depends on the specific use case. In general, UTF-8 without the BOM is preferred, as it is more widely supported and less prone to issues with some software and programming languages. However, in some cases, such as Microsoft Windows, UTF-8 with BOM is required to ensure correct behavior.

INPUT:question:
How can I merge multiple commits onto another branch as a single squashed commit?
I have a remote Git server, here is the scenario which I want to perform:
For each bug/feature I create a different Git branch
I keep on committing my code in that Git branch with un-official Git messages
In top repository we have to do one commit for one bug with official Git message
So how can I merge my branch to remote branch so that they get just one commit for all my check-ins (I even want to provide commit message for this)?
OUTPUT:answer:
o squash multiple commits into a single squashed commit, you can use the git rebase command with the --interactive (or -i) option. Here's the basic process:

    Check out the branch you want to merge your changes into (let's call it the "main" branch).
    Check out the branch you want to merge into the main branch (let's call it the "feature" branch).
    Run the following command: git rebase -i HEAD~<number_of_commits> where <number_of_commits> is the number of commits you want to squash.
    In the text editor that opens, replace the words "pick" next to the commits you want to squash with the word "squash".
    Save and close the text editor. Git will then reapply the changes from each of the squashed commits as a single combined commit.
    Force push the feature branch to the remote repository: git push -f origin feature.
    Now, you can merge the feature branch into the main branch using a normal merge.

Note: the -f option is used to force push the changes to the remote repository, which can overwrite existing history. Use this option with caution.

OUTPUT:answer:
This error message is typically encountered in .NET projects that use the Managed Extensibility Framework (MEF) and it indicates that a required export could not be found.

Here are some steps you can try to fix this issue:

    Check the MEF export and import attributes: Ensure that the export attribute is placed on the correct class and that the import attribute has the correct contract name specified.

    Verify that the required assembly is referenced: Make sure that the assembly containing the export is correctly referenced in your project.

    Ensure the correct version of the assembly is referenced: Check that the correct version of the assembly is referenced, as the MEF only considers exports from the same version of the assembly.

    Check the MEF catalogs: Verify that the correct MEF catalogs are being used and that the required assemblies are included in the catalog.

    Rebuild the solution: Sometimes, simply rebuilding the solution can resolve the issue.

If the error persists after trying these steps, you can also try searching for a solution specific to your project, as the exact cause of this error can vary based on the implementation of MEF in your project.

INPUT:question:
Git: Find the most recent common ancestor of two branches
How to find the most recent common ancestor of two Git branches?
OUTPUT:answer:
You can find the most recent common ancestor (also known as the "merge base") of two Git branches by using the following command:

php

git merge-base <branch1> <branch2>

Where <branch1> and <branch2> are the names of the two branches for which you want to find the common ancestor. The output of the command will be the commit hash of the most recent common ancestor of the two branches.

INPUT:question:
How to send a header using a HTTP request through a cURL call?
I wish to send a header to my Apache server on a Linux box.  How can I achieve this via a cURL call?
OUTPUT:answer:
You can send an HTTP header using a cURL call by using the -H or --header option, followed by the header that you want to send. For example, to send an "Authorization" header with a value of "Bearer abc123", you can use the following command:

javascript

curl -H "Authorization: Bearer abc123" https://example.com

You can specify multiple headers by using multiple -H options. For example:

javascript

curl -H "Header1: value1" -H "Header2: value2" https://example.com

INPUT:question:
Why should text files end with a newline?
I assume everyone here is familiar with the adage that all text files should end with a newline. I've known of this "rule" for years but I've always wondered — why?
OUTPUT:answer:
The reason why text files should end with a newline is because of the way that text editors, utilities, and programming languages typically handle newlines.

Many text editors and utilities, such as cat on Unix-like systems, expect each line of a text file to be terminated with a newline character (\n). If a file does not end with a newline, then these tools may not display the final line of the file, or may display it in a way that is not intended.

In addition, many programming languages, such as Python, treat a newline as a separator between lines of text when reading from a file. If a text file does not end with a newline, then the last line of the file may not be processed correctly when it is read by a program.

Therefore, to ensure consistent and correct behavior across different text editors, utilities, and programming languages, it is a best practice to end all text files with a newline.

INPUT:question:
Turning off auto indent when pasting text into vim
I am making the effort to learn Vim.
When I paste code into my document from the clipboard, I get extra spaces at the start of each new line:
line
  line
    line
I know you can turn off auto indent but I can't get it to work because I have some other settings conflicting or something (which look pretty obvious in my .vimrc but don't seem to matter when I take them out). 
How do I turn off auto indenting when I paste code but still have vim auto indent when I am writing code?  Here is my .vimrc file:
set expandtab  
set tabstop=2  
set shiftwidth=2  
set autoindent  
set smartindent  
set bg=dark  
set nowrap
OUTPUT:answer:
You can turn off auto-indentation when pasting text in Vim by using the :set paste command before you paste, and then using the :set nopaste command after you have finished pasting. For example:

bash

:set paste
# paste your text here
:set nopaste

This temporarily disables Vim's auto-indentation while you paste your text, and then re-enables it once you have finished. With this, your other settings such as autoindent and smartindent will still be in effect when you write code, but will not be applied when you paste text.

INPUT:question:
What is the meaning of "POSIX"?
What is POSIX? I have read the Wikipedia article and I read it every time I encounter the term. The fact is that I never really understood what it is.
Can anyone please explain it to me by explaining "the need for POSIX" too?
OUTPUT:answer:
POSIX (Portable Operating System Interface) is a set of standards for operating system interfaces that were developed by the IEEE (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers) to provide a consistent environment for software development across different operating systems, including Unix, Linux, and macOS.

The need for POSIX arose from the fragmentation of the Unix operating system into different proprietary implementations that were incompatible with each other. This made it difficult for software developers to write applications that could run on multiple Unix systems, since they had to take into account the differences between each system's APIs and user interfaces.

POSIX defines a standard set of system calls, library functions, and user interface conventions that must be supported by a Unix-like operating system in order to be considered POSIX-compliant. By providing a standard interface, POSIX allows software developers to write code that can be easily ported between different Unix systems, without having to worry about differences in system-specific APIs and user interfaces.

POSIX is important because it provides a way for developers to write portable, cross-platform software that can run on different Unix systems with minimal modification. This helps to reduce the cost of software development and maintain compatibility between different operating systems, which is important for users who need to run software on a variety of platforms.

INPUT:question:
WebSockets vs. Server-Sent events/EventSource
Both WebSockets and Server-Sent Events are capable of pushing data to browsers. To me they seem to be competing technologies. What is the difference between them? When would you choose one over the other?
OUTPUT:answer:
WebSockets and Server-Sent Events (SSE) are both technologies that allow a server to push data to a client, but they have different use cases and design goals.

WebSockets are designed for real-time, two-way communication between a client and a server. They provide a full-duplex channel, meaning that data can be sent in both directions simultaneously, and they support a wider range of data types than SSE. WebSockets use a single, long-lived connection between the client and the server, and the connection remains open until either the client or the server closes it. This makes WebSockets suitable for use cases where low latency and high bandwidth are important, such as gaming, real-time chat, or financial data streaming.

Server-Sent Events, on the other hand, are designed for one-way communication from the server to the client, with a simple message-based API. SSE uses a text-based protocol that runs over a standard HTTP connection, which makes it easier to set up and use than WebSockets, especially in scenarios where firewalls or other security mechanisms block WebSockets connections. SSE connections are also designed to automatically reconnect if the connection is lost, making it more resilient than WebSockets in some scenarios. SSE is well suited for use cases where low latency is less important, such as sports updates, weather updates, or news feeds.

When choosing between WebSockets and Server-Sent Events, the most important factors to consider are the type of data you want to transmit, the amount of data you want to transmit, and the desired level of real-time interaction between the client and server. If you need low latency, high bandwidth, two-way communication, and support for binary data, then WebSockets may be the better choice. If you need simple one-way communication and don't need real-time interaction, then Server-Sent Events may be the better choice.

INPUT:question:
Getting error: Peer authentication failed for user "postgres", when trying to get pgsql working with rails
I'm getting the error:
FATAL: Peer authentication failed for user "postgres"
when I try to make postgres work with Rails. 
Here's my pg_hba.conf, my database.yml, and a dump of the full trace.
I changed authentication to md5 in pg_hba and tried different things, but none seem to work. 
I also tried creating a new user and database as per Rails 3.2, FATAL: Peer authentication failed for user (PG::Error)
But they don't show up on pgadmin or even when I run sudo -u postgres psql -l.
Any idea where I'm going wrong?
OUTPUT:answer:
The error "Peer authentication failed for user 'postgres'" is typically caused by a misconfiguration in the PostgreSQL authentication settings. To resolve the issue, you need to make sure that the PostgreSQL server is configured to allow authentication for the user "postgres" and that the credentials in your Rails application's database.yml file are correct.

First, check your pg_hba.conf file to make sure that it's configured to allow authentication for the "postgres" user. Look for a line that specifies the authentication method for the "postgres" user, and make sure it's set to "md5". The line should look something like this:

sql

local   all         postgres                 md5

Next, check your database.yml file to make sure that the credentials for the "postgres" user are correct. Make sure that the "username" and "password" fields are set correctly for the "production" and "development" environments. The relevant sections of the file should look something like this:

yaml

production:
  adapter: postgresql
  encoding: unicode
  database: myapp_production
  username: postgres
  password: mypassword

development:
  adapter: postgresql
  encoding: unicode
  database: myapp_development
  username: postgres
  password: mypassword

If the settings in your pg_hba.conf and database.yml files are correct, but you're still encountering the error, you may need to restart the PostgreSQL server to apply the changes. On most systems, you can do this by running the following command:

sudo service postgresql restart

If the problem persists after restarting the server, try connecting to the PostgreSQL database using the psql client and specify the username and password on the command line. This will help you determine if the issue is with the authentication settings or with the configuration of your Rails application.

psql -U postgres -d myapp_development

If you're still encountering the error after following these steps, it's possible that there's a more complex issue at play, and you may need to consult the PostgreSQL documentation or seek help from the PostgreSQL community for further assistance

INPUT:question:
How can I undo git reset --hard HEAD~1?
Is it possible to undo the changes caused by the following command? If so, how?
git reset --hard HEAD~1
OUTPUT:answer:
Unfortunately, when you use the git reset --hard command, the changes are permanently deleted from your repository and cannot be recovered. However, if you have made a backup of your repository or have a cloned copy, you can use that to recover the lost commits.

If you have not made a backup, you can use the git reflog command to see a list of all the previous values of the HEAD pointer and try to recover the lost commits from there.

Here is an example of how you can use git reflog to recover the lost commits:

    Run git reflog to see a list of all the previous values of the HEAD pointer.

    Find the hash of the commit that you want to recover and copy it.

    Run the following command to reset the HEAD pointer to the commit you want to recover:
    git reset --hard <commit_hash>

    Once you have reset the HEAD pointer, you can use the git log command to confirm that the lost commits have been recovered.

Note: This method is only possible if the reflog information has not been garbage collected. The reflog information is stored for a limited time (default is 90 days) and will eventually be deleted.

INPUT:question:
Why does ++[[]][+[]]+[+[]] return the string "10"?
This is valid and returns the string "10" in JavaScript (more examples here):
console.log(++[[]][+[]]+[+[]])
Why? What is happening here?
OUTPUT:answer:
This expression is an example of a clever use of type coercion in JavaScript. Here's a step-by-step explanation:

    ++[[]][+[]]:
    [] is an empty array, which when coerced to a number becomes 0. +[] is a unary operator that converts the value of its operand to a number, in this case, it becomes 0. So, +[0] is 0. And [0] is an array with one element, so ++[0] is 1.

    [+[]]: +[] is 0, so [0] is an array with one element.

    ++[[]][+[]] + [+[]]: Finally, 1 + [0] is 1 concatenated with [0], which becomes "10".

So, the expression ++[[]][+[]] + [+[]] evaluates to the string "10".

INPUT:question:
How can I do 'insert if not exists' in MySQL?
I started by googling and found the article How to write INSERT if NOT EXISTS queries in standard SQL which talks about mutex tables.
I have a table with ~14 million records. If I want to add more data in the same format, is there a way to ensure the record I want to insert does not already exist without using a pair of queries (i.e., one query to check and one to insert is the result set is empty)?
Does a unique constraint on a field guarantee the insert will fail if it's already there?
It seems that with merely a constraint, when I issue the insert via PHP, the script croaks.
OUTPUT:answer:
To perform an "insert if not exists" in MySQL, you can use the following syntax:

sql

INSERT INTO table_name (column1, column2, column3, ...)
SELECT 'value1', 'value2', 'value3', ...
FROM DUAL
WHERE NOT EXISTS (SELECT 1 FROM table_name WHERE unique_column = 'value');

Here, you are trying to insert new values into the table_name if the values do not already exist in a specific column, unique_column. The SELECT statement is checking if the same values already exist, and if not, the values are inserted.

A unique constraint on a field will ensure that the insert will fail if the value you are trying to insert already exists in that field. However, if you are using PHP and the script is croaking, you may be encountering an error due to the insertion failing due to the constraint. To handle this, you can use try-catch blocks in your PHP code to catch the exception and handle it appropriately.

INPUT:question:

OUTPUT:answer:
You can use the following code to get the path of the application in a .NET console application:

lua

string path = System.IO.Path.GetDirectoryName(System.Reflection.Assembly.GetExecutingAssembly().Location);

The System.Reflection.Assembly.GetExecutingAssembly().Location property returns the full path and file name of the executing assembly. The System.IO.Path.GetDirectoryName method then returns just the directory portion of the path. This gives you the path of the application, which is the directory where the executable is located.

INPUT:question:
What's the difference between a mock & stub?
I've read various articles about mocking vs stubbing in testing, including Martin Fowler's Mocks Aren't Stubs, but still don't understand the difference.
OUTPUT:answer:
Mocks and stubs are both test doubles, or objects that simulate the behavior of other objects in a controlled way during testing. The main difference between them lies in their level of interactiveness and their intended use.

A stub is a test double that returns a pre-defined output when its methods are called, without actually checking the arguments passed to them or whether they are called the right number of times. Stubs are used to replace a real collaborator in a test, and to control the behavior of the system under test by returning hardcoded results.

A mock, on the other hand, is a more sophisticated test double that can verify whether its methods were called, in what order, and with what arguments. Mocks can also define expectations for the number of times a method should be called and raise an exception if those expectations are not met. Mocks are used to verify the interactions between the system under test and its collaborators.

In summary, stubs are used to control the behavior of the system under test, and mocks are used to verify the interactions between the system under test and its collaborators.

INPUT:question:
Get current directory or folder name (without the full path)
How could I retrieve the current working directory/folder name in a bash script, or even better, just a terminal command.
pwd gives the full path of the current working directory, e.g. /opt/local/bin but I only want bin.
OUTPUT:answer:
You can extract just the last part of the full path returned by pwd using parameter expansion in bash:

makefile

current_dir=${PWD##*/}

This sets the variable current_dir to the string following the last / in the value of $PWD, which is the current working directory.

Alternatively, you can use the basename command:

makefile

current_dir=$(basename $PWD)

This sets the variable current_dir to the output of the basename command applied to the value of $PWD.

INPUT:question:
How to concatenate (join) items in a list to a single string
How do I concatenate a list of strings into a single string?
For example, given ['this', 'is', 'a', 'sentence'], how do I get "this-is-a-sentence"?
For handling a few strings in separate variables, see How do I append one string to another in Python?.
For the opposite process - creating a list from a string - see How do I split a string into a list of characters? or How do I split a string into a list of words? as appropriate.
OUTPUT:answer:
In Python, you can concatenate a list of strings into a single string using the join() method of strings:

sql

sentence = ['this', 'is', 'a', 'sentence']
result = '-'.join(sentence)

The join() method is called on a delimiter string, in this case "-", and it concatenates all the elements of the list sentence, separated by the delimiter string. The result is a single string "this-is-a-sentence".

This method works because join() is a string method, not a list method. You can use any string as the delimiter, not just "-". For example, to concatenate the list into a space-separated string, you could use " " as the delimiter:

sql

sentence = ['this', 'is', 'a', 'sentence']
result = ' '.join(sentence)

INPUT:question:
Get size of all tables in database
I have inherited a fairly large SQL Server database. It seems to take up more space than I would expect, given the data it contains.
Is there an easy way to determine how much space on disk each table is consuming?
OUTPUT:answer:
You can determine the size of each table in a SQL Server database using the sys.dm_db_partition_stats dynamic management view. You can use the following query to get the size, in MB, of each table in the database:

css

SELECT
    t.NAME AS TableName,
    SUM(p.rows) AS RowCounts,
    SUM(a.total_pages) * 8 / 1024 AS TotalSpaceMB,
    SUM(a.used_pages) * 8 / 1024 AS UsedSpaceMB,
    (SUM(a.total_pages) - SUM(a.used_pages)) * 8 / 1024 AS UnusedSpaceMB
FROM
    sys.tables t
INNER JOIN      
    sys.indexes i ON t.OBJECT_ID = i.object_id
INNER JOIN 
    sys.partitions p ON i.object_id = p.OBJECT_ID AND i.index_id = p.index_id
INNER JOIN 
    sys.allocation_units a ON p.partition_id = a.container_id
WHERE 
    t.is_ms_shipped = 0 AND i.OBJECT_ID > 255
GROUP BY 
    t.NAME, t.object_id
ORDER BY 
    UsedSpaceMB DESC;

This query joins several system views to retrieve information about each table and its partitions, and summarizes the data to get the row count, total space, used space, and unused space for each table. The WHERE clause excludes system tables and filters the results to only show user-defined tables.

Note that this query is based on the assumption that all tables in the database use the same page size. If your database uses different page sizes, you will need to adjust the calculation of the space usage accordingly.

INPUT:question:
What is an undefined reference/unresolved external symbol error and how do I fix it?
What are undefined reference/unresolved external symbol errors? What are common causes and how to fix/prevent them?
OUTPUT:answer:
An "undefined reference" or "unresolved external symbol" error is a common error in C and C++ programming when compiling and linking code. This error occurs when the compiler cannot find the definition of a symbol that is referenced in the code.

The most common causes of this error include:

    Missing function or variable definition: The symbol is declared in the code but its definition is not provided. This can occur if the definition is in a different source file and the required header file is not included or if the symbol is declared but not defined.

    Incorrect linking order: The libraries and object files are specified in the wrong order on the command line when linking the code. The linker must resolve symbols in the order in which the libraries and object files are specified, so it's important to list them in the correct order.

    Missing library or object file: A required library or object file is not specified on the command line when linking the code. The linker needs to be able to find the definition of all symbols referenced in the code.

    Incorrect library version: The wrong version of a library is linked with the code. The library version used must match the version that was used to compile the code.

To fix an undefined reference error, you need to identify the missing definition and ensure that it is provided. This may involve adding a header file, providing a function or variable definition, specifying a required library or object file on the command line, or linking a compatible version of the library.

Preventing undefined reference errors involves following good coding practices such as providing complete definitions for all symbols, including required header files, and specifying required libraries and object files on the command line. It's also a good idea to thoroughly test your code after making changes to ensure that all symbols are resolved correctly.

INPUT:question:
Python integer incrementing with ++
I've always laughed to myself when I've looked back at my VB6 days and thought, "What modern language doesn't allow incrementing with double plus signs?":
number++
To my surprise, I can't find anything about this in the Python docs. Must I really subject myself to number = number + 1? Don't people use the ++ / -- notation?
OUTPUT:answer:
In Python, the "++" and "--" operators for incrementing and decrementing are not supported. Instead, you have to use the addition and subtraction operators to increment or decrement a variable:

number = number + 1 # to increment
number = number - 1 # to decrement

This syntax is the standard in Python and is more readable than the "++" and "--" operators. Additionally, Python is a dynamically-typed language, so it doesn't have a notion of an "integer" type that would be incremented or decremented in the same way as in statically-typed languages like C or Java.

Styling an input type="file" button

<input type="file" />

Easy interview question got harder: given numbers 1..100, find the missing number(s) given exactly k are missing
I had an interesting job interview experience a while back. The question started really easy:
Q1: We have a bag containing numbers 1, 2, 3, …, 100. Each number appears exactly once, so there are 100 numbers. Now one number is randomly picked out of the bag. Find the missing number.
I've heard this interview question before, of course, so I very quickly answered along the lines of:
A1: Well, the sum of the numbers 1 + 2 + 3 + … + N is (N+1)(N/2) (see Wikipedia: sum of arithmetic series). For N = 100, the sum is 5050.
Thus, if all numbers are present in the bag, the sum will be exactly 5050. Since one number is missing, the sum will be less than this, and the difference is that number. So we can find that missing number in O(N) time and O(1) space.
At this point I thought I had done well, but all of a sudden the question took an unexpected turn:
Q2: That is correct, but now how would you do this if TWO numbers are missing?
I had never seen/heard/considered this variation before, so I panicked and couldn't answer the question. The interviewer insisted on knowing my thought process, so I mentioned that perhaps we can get more information by comparing against the expected product, or perhaps doing a second pass after having gathered some information from the first pass, etc, but I really was just shooting in the dark rather than actually having a clear path to the solution.
The interviewer did try to encourage me by saying that having a second equation is indeed one way to solve the problem. At this point I was kind of upset (for not knowing the answer before hand), and asked if this is a general (read: "useful") programming technique, or if it's just a trick/gotcha answer.
The interviewer's answer surprised me: you can generalize the technique to find 3 missing numbers. In fact, you can generalize it to find k missing numbers.
Qk: If exactly k numbers are missing from the bag, how would you find it efficiently?
This was a few months ago, and I still couldn't figure out what this technique is.  Obviously there's a Ω(N) time lower bound since we must scan all the numbers at least once, but the interviewer insisted that the TIME and SPACE complexity of the solving technique (minus the O(N) time input scan) is defined in k not N.
So the question here is simple:
How would you solve Q2?
How would you solve Q3?
How would you solve Qk?
Clarifications
Generally there are N numbers from 1..N, not just 1..100.
I'm not looking for the obvious set-based solution, e.g. using a bit set, encoding the presence/absence each number by the value of a designated bit, therefore using O(N) bits in additional space. We can't afford any additional space proportional to N.
I'm also not looking for the obvious sort-first approach. This and the set-based approach are worth mentioning in an interview (they are easy to implement, and depending on N, can be very practical). I'm looking for the Holy Grail solution (which may or may not be practical to implement, but has the desired asymptotic characteristics nevertheless).
So again, of course you must scan the input in O(N), but you can only capture small amount of information (defined in terms of k not N), and must then find the k missing numbers somehow.
OUTPUT:answer:
One solution is to use the technique of Gaussian elimination to create a system of linear equations based on the sum and product of the numbers from 1 to N, with k unknowns representing the missing numbers. The system of linear equations can then be solved using matrix operations to find the missing numbers in time and space complexity defined in terms of k.

For Q2 (2 missing numbers), we can create a system of 2 linear equations based on the sum and product of the numbers from 1 to N:

    Sum of all numbers = (N+1)(N/2) - x - y
    Product of all numbers = (N!)/(N-k) = (N!)/(N-2) = x * y
    Where x and y are the missing numbers.

For Q3 (3 missing numbers), we can create a system of 3 linear equations based on the sum and product of the numbers from 1 to N:

    Sum of all numbers = (N+1)(N/2) - x - y - z
    Product of all numbers = (N!)/(N-k) = (N!)/(N-3) = x * y * z
    x + y + z = (N+1)(N/2) - (sum of remaining numbers)

For Qk (k missing numbers), we can extend this approach by creating a system of k linear equations and solving for the k unknowns using matrix operations.

Note that this technique requires a high level of mathematical proficiency and may not be practical for all interview situations. However, it provides a theoretical solution to the problem with the desired time and space complexity defined in terms of k.

INPUT:question:
How do I unload (reload) a Python module?
I have a long-running Python server and would like to be able to upgrade a service without restarting the server. What's the best way do do this?
if foo.py has changed:
    unimport foo  <-- How do I do this?
    import foo
    myfoo = foo.Foo()
OUTPUT:answer:
To unload a Python module, you can use the del statement to remove it from the current namespace. For example:

css

del sys.modules['foo']

After that, you can import the module again with import foo. Note that this only unloads the module from the current namespace. If the module has been imported elsewhere, it will continue to remain in memory.

If you want to reload the module, you can use the importlib module:

python

import importlib
importlib.reload(foo)

This will reload the latest version of the foo module into the current namespace.

INPUT:question:
How do I clone a subdirectory only of a Git repository?
I have my Git repository which, at the root, has two sub directories:
/finisht
/static
When this was in SVN, /finisht was checked out in one place, while /static was checked out elsewhere, like so:
svn co svn+ssh://admin@domain.example/home/admin/repos/finisht/static static
Is there a way to do this with Git?
OUTPUT:answer:
Yes, you can clone a subdirectory only of a Git repository using Git's sparse checkout feature. Here's how to do it:

    Initialize a new Git repository:

bash

git init myrepo
cd myrepo

    Add the remote repository:

csharp

git remote add origin <url-to-remote-repo>

    Configure sparse checkout:

lua

git config core.sparseCheckout true

    Create a file named .git/info/sparse-checkout that lists the subdirectories you want to checkout:

bash

echo "/finisht" > .git/info/sparse-checkout

git pull origin master

After running these commands, only the /finisht subdirectory will be checked out and available in your local repository.

Note that sparse checkout is only available in Git version 1.7.0 or higher.

OUTPUT:answer:
The three dots (...) are called the spread operator in JavaScript, and they are used to spread the properties of an object into a new object.

In this particular code, ...this.props is spreading the properties of the props object of the component into a new object that's passed as props to the Modal component.

So, in this case, all the properties of the component's props object will be passed to the Modal component, but the title and animation properties are being overridden by explicitly setting title='Modal heading' and animation={false}.
