INPUT:question:
How do I force a favicon refresh?
I have a Grails application running locally using its own tomcat and I have just changed the favicon for a new one.  Problem is that I can not see it in any browser.  The old favicon shows up or I get no favicon at all, but not my new one.  I do not think this is a Grails issue per se, more an issue with favicons.
What is supposed to happen with favicons?  How are they supposed to work?  I have numerous bookmarks in my browser which have the wrong icons and they never seem to get refreshed.  How do I force the server/browser to stop caching them?  It seems pretty silly to always cache them given they are normally only 16x16.  Why not just upload them with every visit to the page? It is not exactly a huge overhead.
OUTPUT:answer:
To refresh a favicon, try these steps:

Clear the browser cache. This can typically be done in the browser settings or by using a keyboard shortcut (e.g. Ctrl + Shift + R in Chrome).

Change the file name of the new favicon. This will ensure that the browser is not serving the old file from cache.

Update the HTML code that references the favicon to use the new file name.

Restart the tomcat server to ensure it serves the updated favicon.

Regarding how favicons work, they are typically stored in the root directory of a website and referenced in the HTML code with a link tag in the header section. The browser caches the favicon so that it doesn't have to request it every time the user visits the site. This makes the site load faster but can sometimes result in an outdated favicon if it is not refreshed.

In conclusion, the browser cache and server cache need to be cleared to see the updated favicon. Also, changing the file name and updating the HTML code that references it can ensure that the latest favicon is displayed.

INPUT:question:
JPA EntityManager: Why use persist() over merge()?
EntityManager.merge() can insert new objects and update existing ones.
Why would one want to use persist() (which can only create new objects)?
OUTPUT:answer:
The main difference between persist() and merge() is that persist() only inserts new entities, while merge() can both insert new entities and update existing ones.

In some cases, you may only want to create new entities and not update existing ones. In such scenarios, using persist() is more appropriate. Additionally, persist() is generally considered a simpler operation as it only inserts new entities into the database, and does not require checking the state of the entity being persisted, making it easier to use and less prone to errors.

On the other hand, if you need to update existing entities, then merge() is the better choice, as it checks if the entity already exists and performs an update if it does.

INPUT:question:
What should be in my .gitignore for an Android Studio project?
What files should be in my .gitignore for an Android Studio project?
I've seen several examples that all include .iml but IntelliJ docs say that .iml must be included in your source control.
OUTPUT:answer:
Here is a sample .gitignore file for an Android Studio project:

bash
Copy code
# Built application files
*.apk
*.ap_

# Files for the Dalvik VM
*.dex

# Java class files
*.class

# Generated files
bin/
gen/
out/

# Gradle files
.gradle/
build/

# Local configuration file (sdk path, etc)
local.properties

# Proguard folder generated by Eclipse
proguard/

# Log Files
*.log

# Android Studio Navigation editor temp files
.navigation/

# Android Studio captures folder
captures/

# IntelliJ
.idea/workspace.xml
.idea/tasks.xml
.idea/gradle.xml
.idea/dictionaries

# Keystore files
*.jks

# External native build folder generated in Android Studio 2.2 and later
.externalNativeBuild/

# Google Services (e.g. APIs or Firebase)
google-services.json

# Freeline
freeline.py
freeline/
freeline_project_description.json

# fastlane
fastlane/report.xml
fastlane/Preview.html
fastlane/screenshots
fastlane/test_output

# macOS
.DS_Store

# Windows Thumbs.db
Thumbs.db

# android-studio-ide-<version>.properties
*.properties

# license
*.license

# generated files
generated/
Note: Keep in mind that the actual files and directories you need to ignore may vary depending on your specific project setup, dependencies and tools used.

INPUT:question:
JavaScript post request like a form submit
I'm trying to direct a browser to a different page. If I wanted a GET request, I might say
document.location.href = 'http://example.com/q=a';
But the resource I'm trying to access won't respond properly unless I use a POST request. If this were not dynamically generated, I might use the HTML
<form action="http://example.com/" method="POST">
    <input type="hidden" name="q" value="a">
</form>
Then I would just submit the form from the DOM.
But really I would like JavaScript code that allows me to say
post_to_url('http://example.com/', {'q':'a'});
What's the best cross browser implementation?
I need a solution that changes the location of the browser, just like submitting a form. If this is possible with XMLHttpRequest, it is not obvious. And this should not be asynchronous, nor use XML, so Ajax is not the answer.

Path.Combine for URLs?
Path.Combine is handy, but is there a similar function in the .NET framework for URLs?
I'm looking for syntax like this:
Url.Combine("http://MyUrl.com/", "/Images/Image.jpg")
which would return:
"http://MyUrl.com/Images/Image.jpg"

Best way to use Google's hosted jQuery, but fall back to my hosted library on Google fail
What would be a good way to attempt to load the hosted jQuery at Google (or other Google hosted libs), but load my copy of jQuery if the Google attempt fails?
I'm not saying Google is flaky. There are cases where the Google copy is blocked (apparently in Iran, for instance).
Would I set up a timer and check for the jQuery object?
What would be the danger of both copies coming through?
Not really looking for answers like "just use the Google one" or "just use your own." I understand those arguments. I also understand that the user is likely to have the Google version cached. I'm thinking about fallbacks for the cloud in general.
Edit: This part added...
Since Google suggests using google.load to load the ajax libraries, and it performs a callback when done, I'm wondering if that's the key to serializing this problem.
I know it sounds a bit crazy. I'm just trying to figure out if it can be done in a reliable way or not.
Update: jQuery now hosted on Microsoft's CDN.
http://www.asp.net/ajax/cdn/
OUTPUT:answer:
You can use the following code to load the jQuery library from Google's CDN with a fallback to your own hosted version:

php
Copy code
<script src="https://ajax.aspnetcdn.com/ajax/jquery/jquery-3.6.0.min.js"></script>
<script>
if (!window.jQuery) {
  document.write('<script src="path/to/your/jquery.js"><\/script>');
}
</script>
This will first try to load the jQuery library from Google's CDN. If the library is not loaded or fails to load for any reason, it will then load your own hosted version.

As for the danger of both copies coming through, it is unlikely as the if statement will only attempt to load your version if the Google version is not present. However, to ensure that only one version of the library is loaded, you can use the jQuery.noConflict() method to release control of the $ symbol after the first version is loaded.

INPUT:question:
How do I access the $scope variable in browser's console using AngularJS?
I would like to access my $scope variable in Chrome's JavaScript console. How do I do that?
I can neither see $scope nor the name of my module myapp in the console as variables.
OUTPUT:answer:
You can access the $scope object of a specific AngularJS component in the browser's console by injecting the $rootScope service and then calling $rootScope.$$childHead to get the first child scope. This is useful when you need to debug or inspect the state of your application.

Here is an example in the Chrome JavaScript console:

scss
Copy code
> angular.element($0).scope()
Note: Replace $0 with the DOM element you want to inspect.

Alternatively, you can also use the following command to access the $scope of the controller:

sql
Copy code
> angular.element(document.getElementById('elementId')).scope()
Replace 'elementId' with the actual id of the DOM element you want to inspect.

INPUT:question:
Using Git with Visual Studio
As a long-time Visual SourceSafe user (and hater) I was discussing switching to SVN with a colleague; he suggested using Git instead. Since, apparently, it can be used as peer-to-peer without a central server (we are a 3-developer team).

OUTPUT:answer:
Yes, there are tools that integrate Git with Visual Studio. Visual Studio has built-in support for Git and it provides an integrated Git experience. You can use Git from Visual Studio without leaving the IDE, perform Git operations such as cloning, committing, pushing, and pulling directly from the Visual Studio interface.

Other Git clients such as Git Extensions, Sourcetree, and GitKraken, also have integrations with Visual Studio and provide a graphical user interface for working with Git repositories.

Before you begin, it is important to have a basic understanding of Git and its underlying concepts such as commits, branches, and merge conflicts. You should also be familiar with the Git command line and the Git configuration file.

In summary, the technology available for using Git with Visual Studio include:

Built-in Git support in Visual Studio
Git Extensions
Sourcetree
GitKraken
It's important to choose the one that fits your needs and preferences.

Differences between Lodash and Underscore.js
Why would someone prefer either the Lodash or Underscore.js utility library over the other?

I think both are brilliant, but I do not know enough about how they work to make an educated comparison, and I would like to know more about the differences.
OUTPUT:answer:
Lodash and Underscore.js are JavaScript utility libraries that provide helpful functions for working with arrays, objects, and functions.

The main difference between Lodash and Underscore.js is that Lodash is a more modern and modular library, while Underscore.js is a more traditional and monolithic library. Lodash has a more comprehensive and up-to-date set of features, while Underscore.js is more lightweight and simple.

Lodash has improved performance and has more optimizations, while Underscore.js has a more straightforward and intuitive API.

In terms of choosing between the two, it depends on the specific needs of a project. If performance and a large set of features are important, Lodash may be the better choice. If a lightweight and simple solution is desired, Underscore.js may be a better option.

INPUT:question:
Proper MIME media type for PDF files
When working with PDFs, I've run across the MIME types application/pdf and application/x-pdf among others. 
Is there a difference between these two types, and if so what is it? Is one preferred over the other?
I'm working on a web app which must deliver huge amounts of PDFs and I want to do it the correct way, if there is one.
OUTPUT:answer: The MIME type application/pdf is the official and preferred media type for PDF files. The media type application/x-pdf is not an official media type and might be used in some systems to indicate that the PDF file is encoded in a binary format, as opposed to a text-based format like application/pdf. However, this distinction is not widely recognized or used, and it is best to simply use application/pdf for all PDF files.

INPUT:question:
How to catch and print the full exception traceback without halting/exiting the program?
I want to catch and log exceptions without exiting, e.g.,

    do_stuff()
except Exception as err:
    print(Exception, err)
    # I want to print the entire traceback here,
    # not just the exception name and details
I want to print the exact same output that is printed when the exception is raised without the try/except intercepting the exception, and I do not want it to exit my program.
OUTPUT:answer:
You can use the traceback module to print the full exception traceback:

python
Copy code
import traceback

try:
    do_stuff()
except Exception as err:
    print(traceback.format_exc())
The traceback.format_exc() function returns a string representation of the traceback, which you can print to the console or log. This will give you the same output that you would see if the exception was not caught.

INPUT:question:
How are lambdas useful?
I'm trying to figure out Python lambdas. Is lambda one of those "interesting" language items that in real life should be forgotten?
I'm sure there are some edge cases where it might be needed, but given the obscurity of it, the potential of it being redefined in future releases (my assumption based on the various definitions of it) and the reduced coding clarity - should it be avoided?
This reminds me of overflowing (buffer overflow) of C types - pointing to the top variable and overloading to set the other field values.  It feels like sort of a techie showmanship but maintenance coder nightmare.
OUTPUT:answer:
Lambdas in Python are small, anonymous functions that can be used for short, single-use functions. They are often used as inputs to higher-order functions, such as map, filter, and reduce, where a function is needed as an argument. They can also be used in place of a named function in cases where the function is used only once and its definition would make the code less readable.

In general, lambdas are not a necessary feature in Python, and in many cases, a named function is a clearer and more maintainable option. However, they can be useful in certain specific scenarios where the function is simple, used only once, and the code would be more readable if it were inlined. It ultimately depends on the specific use case and the preference of the programmer.

INPUT:question:
What is JavaScript's highest integer value that a number can go to without losing precision?
Is this defined by the language? Is there a defined maximum? Is it different in different browsers?
OUTPUT:answer: The highest integer value that a JavaScript number can represent without losing precision is approximately 1.79E+308. This is defined by the IEEE 754 standard for floating-point arithmetic, which JavaScript follows. However, it's important to note that JavaScript uses a 64-bit floating-point format, which can lead to loss of precision for very large or very small numbers. The maximum value is not defined by the language itself but by the underlying hardware and the IEEE standard. The behavior should be consistent across all modern browsers, as they all implement JavaScript according to the same standard.

INPUT:question:
How to cherry-pick multiple commits
I have two branches. Commit a is the head of one, while the other has b, c, d, e and f on top of a. I want to move c, d, e and f to first branch without commit b. Using cherry pick it is easy: checkout first branch cherry-pick one by one c to f and rebase second branch onto first. But is there any way to cherry-pick all c-f in one command?
Here is a visual description of the scenario (thanks JJD):
OUTPUT:answer:
Yes, you can cherry-pick multiple commits in one command by specifying the range of commit hashes to be cherry-picked. For example, if the commit hashes of c, d, e, and f are abc123, def456, ghi789, and jkl012, respectively, you can use the following command:

ruby
Copy code
$ git checkout first-branch
$ git cherry-pick abc123^..jkl012
The ^ symbol specifies the parent commit of the current commit, and .. specifies a range of commits. In this case, the range abc123^..jkl012 specifies all the commits from the parent of c (abc123) to f (jkl012), inclusive.

INPUT:question:
When is a CDATA section necessary within a script tag?
Are CDATA tags ever necessary in script tags and if so when?
In other words, when and where is this:
<script type="text/javascript">
//<![CDATA[
...code...
//]]>
</script>
preferable to this:
<script type="text/javascript">
...code...
</script>
OUTPUT:answer:
A CDATA section within a script tag is not necessary for most modern browsers and HTML standards, as they treat the text inside the script tag as plain text. However, it can be used when the script code contains characters (such as "<" and "&") that are reserved in HTML and can cause parsing issues. In those cases, the CDATA section acts as a wrapper to escape these characters and ensure the code is interpreted correctly.

In summary, the use of a CDATA section in script tags is a matter of preference and best practice, but is not required for modern browsers and HTML standards.

OUTPUT:answer:
To delete a Git repository that was created with "git init", simply delete the entire directory that contains the repository. This will remove the repository, along with all its commits and files, from your system.

If you would like to start a new Git repository in the same location, simply navigate to that directory in your terminal or command prompt and run the command "git init" again.

INPUT:question:
Create a branch in Git from another branch
I have two branches: master and dev
I want to create a "feature branch" from the dev branch.
Currently on the branch dev, I do:
git checkout -b myfeature dev
... (some work)
git commit -am "blablabla"
git push origin myfeature
But, after visualizing my branches, I got:
--**master**
------0-----0-----0-----0-----0
------------------------**dev**----**myfeature**
I mean that the branch seems fast-forward merged, and I don't understand why...
What am I doing wrong?
How can you branch off from another branch and push back to the remote repository for the feature branch?
All that in a branching model like the one described here.
OUTPUT:answer:
You are not doing anything wrong. The fast-forward merge is the default behavior in Git when there are no changes on the base branch that you are merging into. In your case, since there were no changes on the dev branch after you created the myfeature branch from it, Git fast-forwarded the myfeature branch to the dev branch.

If you want to create a new branch that is not fast-forwarded, you need to make sure there are changes on the base branch after you create the new branch. For example, you could create a new commit on the dev branch and then create the myfeature branch:

php
Copy code
# switch to the dev branch
git checkout dev
# make a new commit on the dev branch
git commit --allow-empty -m "empty commit"
# create the myfeature branch
git checkout -b myfeature
Now you should be able to push the myfeature branch to the remote repository without a fast-forward merge.

The difference between the three is:

Simple Name: getSimpleName() returns the simple name of the underlying class as given in the source code. This is just the name of the class without the package information.
Canonical Name: getCanonicalName() returns the canonical name of the underlying class, which is the fully qualified name (including the package name) of the class.
Class Name: getName() returns the binary name of the class, which is the fully qualified name (including the package name) of the class, but with '.' replaced with '/' for compatibility with the class file format.
For example, if a class is named com.example.MyClass, the following would be the result:

Simple Name: MyClass
Canonical Name: com.example.MyClass
Class Name: com/example/MyClass

INPUT:question:
Using HTML5/Canvas/JavaScript to take in-browser screenshots
Google's "Report a Bug" or "Feedback Tool" lets you select an area of your browser window to create a screenshot that is submitted with your feedback about a bug.
Screenshot by Jason Small, posted in a duplicate question. 
How are they doing this?  Google's JavaScript feedback API is loaded from here and their overview of the feedback module will demonstrate the screenshot capability.
OUTPUT:answer: Google uses JavaScript to capture screenshots in the browser. This is done by utilizing the HTML5 canvas element, which allows you to dynamically generate and render graphics in the browser. JavaScript is used to capture the contents of the canvas, which can then be submitted as part of the feedback report. The specific implementation details of Google's screenshot tool can be found in their JavaScript feedback API and feedback module documentation.

The issue is that the server you are trying to fetch data from is not sending an "Access-Control-Allow-Origin" header in its response, indicating that it is not allowing cross-origin requests from your domain. The "Access-Control-Allow-Origin" header is required for CORS to work, and it specifies which domains are allowed to make requests to the API.

You can try setting the "Access-Control-Allow-Origin" header to "*" to allow requests from any domain, but this is not recommended as it could open up security vulnerabilities. It's better to specify the exact domains that are allowed to make requests to the API.

Another option is to use a proxy server to fetch the data from the API. This way, the proxy server would make the request to the API, and your JavaScript code would make a request to the proxy server. The proxy server would then send the response back to your code, so the "Access-Control-Allow-Origin" header would not be an issue.

You can also use the "mode: 'no-cors'" option in the fetch call, but this would disable CORS and the response would not include any of the required headers or cookies, so it's not recommended for most use cases.
